The health benefits are very good.

For low-level business sales, the hourly pay rate (about $23/hour) is actually livable. It's not a comfortable living, but you can pay your bills on the base pay, which is nice.

If you want a career in sales and are willing to move, this is a good starting point. Most inside sales reps can promote to field sales in a different city after 15 months, and the pay starts to get more comfortable at that level.

If you enjoy fast-paced, relentless sales, you'll like the job.

Once global travel resumes, you do get to fly standby at decent prices.

When you clock off for the day, you're done. No overtime, no staying late... just carry the stress home with you and let it bubble overnight.
Work life balance and longevity
cons: Difficult, Difficult, Difficult, Difficult, Difficult.
Management test good environment test
You must be driven and motivated to create and work your schedule weekly in order to succeed.
There are no cons for this company.
Overwork tiring and exhausted overwhelming
Soreness, Injury Risk, Hourly Pay, Work / Life Balance, Day Shift Availability
Limited to career advancement for everyone
Poor salary, not enough leadership skills

Career opportunities outside of sales are nearly nonexistent, despite what management will say in your interview. People can move out of sales if they're creative in finding ways to network, which management in the sales office will not be very helpful with.
The path to move up is through field sales. If you're unable to move, or don't want to stay in sales, the best of luck to you.

While the hourly pay is livable, you're unlikely to receive the bonus checks you hear about in the offer letter. 80% of the Dallas office does not bonus for the quarter. It's not a question of work ethic. FedEx is struggling as a company, and it's a very difficult market to be competitive in. Whether or not your territory has potential is luck of the draw.

Since FedEx is doing so poorly right now globally, upper management has put all of its efforts into straining the sales team to do more, constantly. The difficulty of this is exacerbated by the antiquated internal systems that take minutes to hours to struggle through for things like pricing proposals.

The number of sales calls you're expected to make continues to grow to ever more unrealistic levels. While it's possible to make all the calls, emails, and sales opportunities that are expected of you each day, it's unsustainable. I've cycled through my list of customers, some more than once over, in the last month because I'm constantly trying to reach the daily call metric.

If dialing the phone were your only responsibility, it might make sense, but you're also expected to draft pricing proposals and present them to close business. If you spend an hour researching and drafting pricing, and then you spend another hour presenting it, this counts as one sales call in your daily metrics.
According to management, at this point, you've had an extremely unproductive day with your one measly call. Whether or not your time is spent growing revenue is irrelevant.

With such an emphasis on arbitrary daily metrics, there isn't much opportunity to actually do the job you're hired to do, which would be closing business.
All this said, I haven't mentioned how much time it can take to help resolve customer issues. You're constantly told by management to let customer service handle complaints and issues- your job is to sell. Fair enough, but customer service seems to be trained to send customers to their account executive when they aren't sure how to handle something. 

This means that any time you spend not working toward your daily metrics counts as not working. If you're fixing something for a customer, working to create revenue for a company by making proposals, or doing something as important as assisting a teammate with a problem, you are wasting your time in the eyes of management.

There's not enough time in a work day, and there's not enough resources to do the job. All of the complaints I've listed have been discussed with varying levels of management, and are consistently discarded as a personal problem with time management.

TLDR: you're expected to constantly do more, your efforts are hardly appreciated, and when you try to make suggestions for improvement, you're ignored. You feel undervalued as a FedEx employee during these times. The company is struggling, and is trying to get every bit of mileage out of you it can.

I would only recommend this job to someone who lives and breathes selling. Otherwise, this job is not worth the stress.

Specifically, the sourcing and procurement org in the FedEx services operating company is an absolute nightmare, and that’s putting it lightly. Egotistical management, severe lack of true leadership skills, disingenuous, disinterested in employee opinions, and rule with an iron fist. Many stakeholders want nothing to do with our management team, which makes an ICs life miserable. A large number of employees have jumped ship over the past few months, which is only going to continue based on the amount of current employees looking for new jobs.  But that’s ok, because new hires will be cheaper.

My position at FedEx Services as a Project Management Analyst has been incredible. Benefits? Incredible. Work-Life Balance? Incredible. Culture? Incredible. The management team has been kind, supportive, consistent, fair,  intelligent and dependable. In less than a year, I have had 3 managers (my hiring manager, the organization re-org'd after providing a buyout, and then my manager moved over to fill a hard-to-fill management spot to allow an individual contributor to move up) . All three managers have been as I described above. FedEx in general gives you all the tools to do your job properly. They live the People-Service-Profit culture, and you have an army of people willing to help if you need it. VP & Director communication is impressive. And while I'm excited about my promotion to Express, I am sad to part Services and this wonderful organization. 

As far as the physical environment, the cubicles are neat and consistent. Large with a decent amount of filing space. The buildings are shaped in a circular fashion, where all of the backs face each other, and out of the back door, you have a large park area where there is patio furniture, walking trail, and just beautiful, serene area if you need it. One of the buildings has an immaculate gym. They also have a cafeteria of sorts which has a standard hot and cold sandwich place, awesome salad bar, 2 soups, and then one 'guest' spot where companies like Chick-Fil-A come in.
You won't get fired unless you really screw up

Time off: You get Monday off gauranteed, and then one more day that isn't Friday, Saturday or Sunday and people rarely get Tuesday off.  2 weeks vacation after a year. You only get a handfull of missed days allowed. 
Start time varies: When it's busy in the winter around the holidays, start times can be at 6:30 or earlier (I've had a 4:45am start time), and some days when it's slow it doesn't start until 10:45am and then gets out at 2:15 on slow days and 5:00pm or later on busy days.  Hours can lead to great paychecks, but slow periods can be slow.

With such a broad range of positions, it's easy to move between workgroups to continue learning and to avoid boredom in any single position.

As an enterprise, FedEx is supported by an outstanding corporate reputation and one of the strongest, most recognizable brands in the world. Our position at the crossroads of global commerce and transportation makes FedEx and its business performance a leading economic indicator. Led by our founder, chairman, president and CEO Fred Smith, our senior leadership is widely respected in the investment community for its conservative approach and its commitment to long-term growth.

With our roots and core businesses in air and ground transportation, FedEx and its business performance are highly vulnerable to fluctuations in oil and fuel costs. In periods of escalating energy prices, FedEx -- like many businesses -- must manage costs very carefully and adjust short- and long-term priorities accordingly. Although FedEx has long adhered to an unofficial "no layoff" policy, this often leads to the discontinuation of many projects in mid-stream.

While FedEx revenues are increasingly global, our core domestic express business has reached a plateau of maturity and is facing additional headwinds from the U.S. economy and a weaker U.S. dollar that limits demand for imports in the United States.

You have the opportunity to experience a variety of job duties/ skills/ settings & can get extra hours if you choose to (especially Nov.-Dec.). They train & promote FAIRLY from within the company WITHOUT UNION/  DUES! The work offers plenty of exercise & a great team environment! If there's something you dislike about your job/ location/ shift/ group, then following a predetermined waiting period (length depends on position/ available openings), you are free to bid on another position/ location of your choice. They offer excellent benefits/ incentives ( medical, dental, optical, 401K, paid vacation, bonuses, up to $3,000/ yr toward tuition reimbursement, flight/ hotel/ rental car/ cellphone service discounts, & more)! FedEx employs a very diverse group of people, including some who are hearing impaired. You can attend/ get involved with our many community/ charity events. GREAT job security = NO LAY-OFFS to date! High pay rate for PT work. EXCELLENT opportunity for students!

FedEx makes you feel like you make the world go around (later, you realize you actually do!) - you are taught to live something we call the Purple Promise that simply states "I will make every FedEx experience outstanding". Very soon, you realize that dock loaders, desk workers, strategists, individual contributors, managers and executives actually believe this stuff and care about not just getting the job done but they actually care how you felt before, during and after you did it!! Very strange to most people under pressure to perform but the level of buy-in at the highest levels of the company shows newcomers right away that this company truly puts people first. If you're not feeling good about doing something, they want to know why - genuinely and fix it before you proceed. 
Quality Driven Management - This program has roots into every nook and cranny of operations and IT. FedEx  truly believes in continuously improving to get better, finding better ways of doing things, being more efficient, gaining new skills and always pushing the boundaries of achievement while at the same time encouraging employees to live heavy family lives, taking vacations, flexible work from home options (mandatory 2 weeks of work from home) etc.
When you're feeling this good about your work and your contributions, I challenge you to put out poor work - you can't - it's not possible.

Not long hours and easy simple job
cons: There are some groups which are not as friendly.  Overall, this company is not as friendly as the last corporation where I was employed - I think this has to do with the international flavor of FedEx versus the last corporation where I worked most of the people were from the Southern US.  It often takes a while to find out who the correct people are to be working with on any given project because the company is so gigantic and along with that comes an enormous amount of red tape from legal and those processes many times hold projects up for an unecessary amount of time.

The fact that it is such a great and stable company makes for some complacent employees in some cases, and some groups are quite insulated/resistant to change. Every group is different, but it's not uncommon to find a team that just cruises and doesn't really try to push the envelope (including managers). Additionally, size of organization makes for a lot of overhead when trying to institute any kind of change, as there are many disparate groups/processes that must align. They historically haven't been stellar with integrating acquisitions; however, this is improving (particularly in relation to the TNT acquisition).
Lack of communication and poor management, must move to really excel in career.

The pay is not competitive with other large companies and it is not equitable. You must negotiate negotiate negotiate!  You also do not receive stock offering as with some other large companies. I have found that peers, some with less experience than myself, actually make a great deal more than me (10-20,000). Pay seems to be based on your ability to negotiate coming in the door and management's willingness to be fair. I don't want to say race/age plays much of a factor, but as with any large company there are some inequalities here as well. There is not much room to negotiate increases when promoted as there is a standard increase that is not based on performance. Bonus is based on performance but even this is political, and done via a ranking process against peers who are not even on the same team doing the same work.

pros: FedEx  is ...very big... on nudging employees to increase their knowledge-base. This action is required because the firm has sophisticated financial modeling tools that rely on its incredibly huge data-base, which covers its customer's shipping habits, and the corresponding costs. One example: An Services Department employee needs to become pretty well schooled with SQL and other database management tools. FedEx offers a number of "live" training classes in addition to on-line-based coursework, which greatly helps the employee develop or fine-tune code-writing skills.

Management and HR have people first policy. Organization has teams with diverse ethnic and professional background which helps employees to develop strong conflict resolution, sportive spirit, relationship and team skills. Team members on many projects are spread across the country and on corporate projects members are drawn from international locations. This is both challenging for those that lack experience in working with large teams and helps develop project mgmt experience with national and international members. This company has very good reward system, tution reimbursement and many certification classes without charge. Professional growth, discipline, setting targets, goals and innovation is supported strongly through quarterly or monthly performance reviews using 1-on-1 sessions. Entire management has a candid open door policy for discussions that involve objectives, personal and professional growth with employees though it is important as professional ethics to schedule an appointment first. Also focus on work-life balance is wonderful. Management encourages innovation and loves "can do" positive attitudes. Also after work, I participated in more types of sports with other employees while working for this esteemed organization than in my entire adult and education life.
cons: Required training session, either live or taught on-line, are often a big time-sink. This, particularly when the school session occurs during a workday. Project deadlines always loom, so the required training classwork... in a live classroom setting... can materially eat-away at a productive day. The on-line based training programs, particularly with database management, can be very arduous... the text-based product MUST BE VERY CLOSELY READ in order to move-up to the next module. A live training class would offer hands-on help quickly vs. a website-session that might require the student hours to catch-on to the same topic. However, the live classes are traditionally only during the workday.  I suggest offering evening and weekend "live" training sessions... particularly when it involves learning how to effectively use powerful but high degree of difficulty tools... like SQL.

 Management and trainers are very focused on numbers and productivity and not so focused on their people. "Get those package per hour rates up" and "don't waste company time," are the only messages  I receive. 

Anxious micro managers and people with anger issues are the norm the higher up in the company you go. I witnessed a higher up angrily literally screaming at the top of his lungs across the facility at an employee, like a crazy person. My trainer followed me around constantly correcting every tiny behavior, even things that are up to personal interpretation, even after 2 weeks of being employed.

It is a great company where employees are valued. Employees are rewarded based on performance. So a good, hard worker with lots of initiative will find a very favorable environment for lots of personal and professional growth. Their commitment to people is deep. Letting an employee go, or a group of employees, is only ever done as a very last resort. The benefits package is one of the best, and it is still mostly paid for by the company. There are many opportunities for special recognition and reward. The bonus program is based on performance of the company as well as the employee.
cons: The work isn't consistent
Great pay for a good cause too work for them

1. HORRIFICALLY political environment and bureaucratic.  Small minded, Memphis mentality goes into all decisions on every level

2. Jobs don't correlate to reality of what a person should do--salespeople don't really sell, they are more account managers who do glorified admin work (e.g. invoicing, claims, chasing packages) and marketing is really product development--at ANY other company, the product development functions would be a prod development team and marketing would actually do MARKETING.  There is NEVER a reason for a marketing person to get a PMP certification....but they pretty much force you to do it.  

3. Once you become a manager, you are protected from any sort of criticism or feedback.  PULSE was a joke and they did away with it to where you couldn't even give management feedback.  They ended up watering it down to a "general" department talking session, which accomplishes nothing at all 

4. All good ideas must die at some point--no real chance to take ownership of a project and see it until the end.  

5. APEX has turned performance management into a nightmare.  They "recenter" you until your review fits into what your manager wants and they will make up bogus things to have you work on for the future.
Zero advancement.  Have not had a full bonus since '07 despite record company performance.  This year, no bonus and no raises over 2%.

Depending on the manager, some are lazier then others. Men will do more physical work then the women ALL THE TIME! In December they call it BLACK OUT, meaning starting the second week in December until after Christmas you will NOT be able to take any days off PERIOD! Also FedEx fiscal year starts June 1st and ends May 31st, so everyone has to bid on days off for their vacation. So it goes by seniority which means if you were hired after everyone in the company you will get wants left for the days off. meaning if two people already put in for those vacation days you won't even have a chance to get those days off. This happens every year! One guy I work with has been wanting to get Thanksgiving Eve & Christmas Eve off for the last 5 years, but because two other people have been with the company a little while longer and request those day every year HE NEVER GETS THOSE DAYS OFF! He has a family with young kids!
Very pushy, constantly urging you to go quicker even though they pound into your head firing training safety 1st.

It is a corporation. So some of the same problems of red tape and policy slowdowns that exist at other corporations exist here. Also, being a corporation, there are some silo'd groups within the organization. But upper management has been working to resolve those silo issues for the past few years. While a motivated and talented person will find the performance based atmosphere very beneficial, someone just looking for a place to collect a paycheck will find an environment that moves and adapts quickly. If you are looking for a repetitive, predictable task job, you won't find what you are looking for here. Be prepared for new adventures and challenges every few weeks.

Great place to work at. Great management. Manager and supervisors are very friendly. They makde sure you work, but they don't push you to your limits, and they usually don't make you work overtime. Work is fast-paced, but not extremely fast. Do the best you can, don't stand around daydreaming and you'll be fine. If you're not used to activate work YOU WILL FEEL IT THE FIRST DAY, but after a day or two, your body will get accustomed to it and you'll barely feel a thing. Do wear protective gear: gripping gloves and FOREARM SLEEVES, I personally recommend the latter to avoid too much bruising. Pay is decent, and you get A LOT of good benefits even as a part-time employee, provided that you stay a while. If you're looking for a part- time job, LOOK NO FURTHER, FedEx is the place to be! Also worth mentioning, is how easy it is to get hired. I was hired after a week of attending a Sort Observation. When they call you back, show them that you're interested and you're basically in.

I left after a 3 years when I found something better out of town.  The Legal department runs the company and is so risk averse that FedEx is way behind the curve in delivering solutions for customers.  The volatile prices of energy makes it difficult to plan project costs, and projects that are running great are frequently canceled because of cost reductions.  If you are in Services, there are not enough titles and salary bands are too wide to count on regular promotions.  IT's Directors and VPs are very weak leaders and there really isn't anyone among them that has a remarkable understanding of technology or business.  There are not enough young people at FedEx to learn from and cultivate them into leaders.  Memphis is an awful area to live and there's no talent to draw from it.

Some micro-management from upper management.  Benefits have lessened over the past few years and it is rare now to get 100% of bonus.  Usually attain between 25-50% now since they changed how it is paid out.  When I started 100 -120% attainment was considered normal.  It used to be based on station performance alone.  Now it is based on local, operating company performance, and corporate performance.  If FedEx decides to buy 100 new planes, it now affects your bonus.  I wouldn't mind the new structure as long as it was attainable.  Seems like they always have a reason for not paying out complete bonuses, even when then company is doing well.  We haven't come close to 100% since they changed it.
had to stand for a long time

No direction or vision from leadership. Every new project or initiative is a top priority before finishing the previous top priority project or initiative. Bureaucry is more important than customers or innovation.

Wouldn't recommend for new college graduates who are still fresh & looking to develop their job skills quick as there's tendency to specialize in few job roles and not too exciting for workaholics, u may be bored with no work to do at times. Low stuff turnover, meaning very limited opportunities for growth to the next level.

Very inclusive company, positive working environment, encourages teamwork and has solid ethical enforcement. Management is selected well. Build consistent and positive relationships with regular customers, and really feel like you're helping them out with high-priority situations, from important shipments to wedding invitations and funeral memorials.

Great work life balance. Sr Mgmt encourages a lot of community work. 
Good pay. Cost of living is pretty low compared to major cities. Pay hikes are pretty low. 
Interesting Business problems. Constantly changing economic landscapes has us doing a lot of analytics to support business decisions. Strong analytics forms the backbone of a number of group in fedex.
Lot of focus on employee training and developing leadership. Management is very friendly and easily accessible. every major life event (marriages, birthdays, babies) are celebrated with a lot of joy. Lot of ongoing community work during office hours as part of corporate responsibility.

High octane, high stress environment with little to no downtime.  They give you a laptop and a cell phone and you had better be attached to them 24/7. Job is already stressful enough as is with so much multi-tasking involved, but then you're also expected to push sales of specific items each month, plus packing services (when you sometimes don't even have proper time to package items).

They tell you work and life will be balanced but here always short staff cutting hours and hiring kids right out of high school who see one take the job seriously so if you show any sign of being a good worker they'll call you every day off bug you non stop and if you tell them know you'll find your schedule being altered or "adjusted" to fit the world flow regardless. It starts off cozy then once you warm up to people you learn it's a colony you can't tell them no I've work 60 hour weeks 3 weeks in a row I'd like a day off. high drama and gossip a lot of managers have been in place since the 70s and 80s a lot of 20+ year vets that have a hard time connecting with newer generations that leads to trash talk behind their backs and other petty actions I wish I can say this is just 1 out of a few stores but I've worked as a team memeber and a manager at pretty much 7 out of 11 Boston stores and it's just about the same.

review: A great company to be at!

pros: There isn't much I can't say! I've never worked for a company this amazing. I've had a lot of different jobs and coming to Fedex has been a beautiful wake up. This will be the place I retire from. 'The FedEx way' was shown to me the first two weeks in the door. 99.9 percent of people I have met have been nothing but kind and love their jobs! Resources are everywhere and encouraged to use! This company treats you like family and has strong family values. Positive encouragement is passed out on a regular basis and negativity is not welcome. The benefits are outstanding! Management and above listens to everyone and your effort is appreciated. The team activities are fun and never feel forced. I am so grateful to be part of the Fedex family. If you have the chance - don't miss out!

benefits
growing opportunities
helpful managers
increase wages
food and water supplies

Company culture is great, very positive towards customers and employees. We're all in it together. The old "absolutely, positively" ethic is still alive at FedEx. Cost of living is low compared to pay for the Memphis area locations. Benefits are good, especially work life balance. My manager always says, "Work to live, don't live to work." FedEx is one of the largest shipping companies in the world, so we get to work on some of the largest, most interesting business challenges in the world.
Great company. I was proud to work for them. However, I think it is built on the back of the couriers, pilots, and hub people and delivers packages on time despite current poor IT support.
Great Pay, Great benefits, Great perks.

The people are amazing. Management really cares about their people, helping them to learn and grow. What you think is really hard is not. I left seeking more money. I work twice the hours with less appreciation and the work is so much harder. At some point you have to decide what is important. If it is family and security with work/life balance and a place that encourages great customer service and volunteerism - stay at FedEx! I had 6 weeks vacation that I was encouraged to use. I will never ever get that again.

Excellent brand that gets you in the door with companies you call upon. Also helps to have the FedEx name at your back when you have to prospect for new business.  You have the ability to plan your days the way you want around your schedule, so work life balance is great.  The relationships you build are great because you're helping people with their business.  Competition is usually FedEx vs UPS.  Plenty of opportunities if you want to move around in the company.
everything is unbelievable here at fed ex

Great company to work if you like work life balance.  The benefits used to be great many years ago, but its not too bad now either.  The salaries are very standard.  They pay enough for the kind of jobs they have.  If you are a software engineer who has enough skills to get by programming languages, understand a few design patterns, have basic knowledge of software engineering and prefer a laid back work environment, so you can have enough time for family this is the place to be.

It is like being part of a professional sports team at FedEx Ground. Management doesn't force too much down your way, but you are an essential cog of the wheel. It is an easy job to get, but it takes art and strength to keep it past even the trial period. If you get good and do it correctly, it is a great exercise.
cons: Pay is a little low for the field. The interview process can be overwhelming and can make you almost walk away. Don't! The cons really aren't here. If the pay was a tad higher I think this company would literally be the top company to work for!

hard work

Very hot or cold
too much pressure to work

FedEx (and its divisions) are a very large, mature company. Bureaucracy is the norm for large companies. It is easy to get lost in the masses. Advancement opportunities can be hard to find in many parts of the corp, unless you have a senior manager champion who wants you promoted. There is an entrenched good-old-boy network which can be hard to crack. Look out if/when Fred Smith retires.

The company has become mired in the mud due to new processes implemented over the last few years. It is impossible to get anything done for the users. Small fixes take an act of Congress to load to production, much more than they are worth. So anything but the most fatal of errors is never scheduled for work. Paperwork occupies most of a developers time. Don't go there if you like to make things *work* for your users.
Dock Workers are treated like trash.

When you have been here for 10 years you see other, "newer models" coming in and making more money than you do. It is really discouraging. All I wanted was market value for my hard work and couldn't get it. They backfilled my position, turned over two people and then ended up paying more than what I asked for.

Onboarding is really poor. The training you receive is good on a corporate level, but there's so much to learn that it's a 'trial by fire' mentality while learning from your other reps in the area.  their plate is full, too, so if you don't have any team players, you could be screwed. It's a general consensus that you don't feel remotely comfortable until at least a year on the job. Expectations of calls per day is not set in stone, but it might come up if you're not performing and consistently closing business. If you thrive off of a team atmosphere and interaction with team members, this is not the job for you.  Perform or they won't hesitate to manage you out.
I have no cons to offer at this moment

If you are highly innovative and spirited as an engineer, this place is a total letdown.  FedEx is a transporation based company, not a technology company.  Their ideas in innovation are still dated and go real slow in releasing the latest and greatest of products.  Their business model is highly process based, even though some departments take pride of releasing new products as services to existing customers.  Just as any large company, FedEx also has a lot of red tape and bureaucracy.  If you work in the company for a long time, you will be in the dangerous zone of letting your skills become obsolete or unused.  You have to make an effort on your own to stay up to date with the industry.

The primary position requires that you scan 300 barcodes an hour and lift 70 lbs. quite regularly and if you can't take that you will not be around long. Most people actually do make it. There are sirens and the constant noise of the conveyor, earplugs might save the valuable hairs of your inner ear.

Stable job, you're not likely to get fired or laid off.  Good benefits.  Tuition reimbursement.  On-site classes by staff as well as vendors.  On-site gym and cafeteria.  The tech campus is located in a quiet residential area.  Some groups have a laid-back atmosphere, I see people having 6-hour work days and getting away with it.  However, there are teams that have strict deadlines and 70-hour work weeks.  It really depends on which group you're in.

An example of how a greedy company buys/acquires another and attempts to take away everything unique about it and turn it into the same type of business as every other office store in America gone completely wrong. FedEx attempted to completely rebrand Kinko's and in my opinion has failed miserably at it, cost themselves so much revenue expanding and offering overpriced retail products customers can find elsewhere for  a fraction of the cost. After failing to meet revenue goals due to the excess revenue spent cleaning up their mess take it out on their employees by getting rid of salary increases and cutting hours.

Work ethic tends to be somewhat lax.   Customer service is given a lot of lip service, but many employees and managers find excuses to cut corners at the expense of the customer.   Training is somewhat lax, and employee performance could be improved if methods and accountability were of a higher standard.   But again, I came from "the Other Company" where standards were higher....  The best employees at FedEx are those who are self-directed and have high personal standards.  Management won't hold you to high standards unless they themselves have them.
Its all about who you know to advance. Family work life balance is nonexistent.

I have heard that it is difficult to move up the ladder in the technical direction, so many people go into management to be able to advance their careers.  Sometimes policies such as time off and working from home are not clear, things are often done by personal arrangement with the manager.  
If you are a conservative married middle-aged Southern American, you'll feel right at home at FedEx.  If that description does not apply to you, you might have difficulty trying to fit in socially.  Again, this depends on your particular team, but if you're unlucky enough to be the opposite of this description, be prepared for the possibility of social isolation and fear of expressing your individuality.

review: One of the best big companies to work for
Quality Driven Management - Make it Work!
pros: FedEx people are pleasant to work with. The company does things to offer a lot of training and development for its employees. They put more into training and development than other company I've worked for. They also are very diverse and believe in putting high quality people in positions to succeed. The benefits are also excellent, particularly if you live in Memphis.
Salary and potential to earn weekly bonuses

Amazing benefits go well beyond health care, includes 24/7 Nurse on call. Also work/Life Balance counselors. Too much to list here.  Retiree benefits are also wonderful as long as you are 55 yrs. and have 20 yrs with company. Make a career with FedEx and you can be financially secure when you retire. Part time employees entitled to healthcare benefits, 401k, pension and life insurance just as full time employees. Great opportunity for growth and movement throughout the company and the country should you ever want to relocate.
Simple job, good hours, decent managers
Good hours for family time if you know the area

- Being able to work from one store to another sometimes.
- Nice uniforms. That was nice.

Puts employees FIRST. I love that the founder makes it a priority to recognize the employees as being the reason for company success. Several perks, and programs are available to ensure we are taken care of. Pay is good, morale is good! I am still considered a “puppy” with “ONLY” 17yrs here!! There is a reason folks stay- we bleed purple. Amazing company to work for. It’s an honor and privilege!
Good benefits and pay. Can be a rewarding job.
Benefits, PTO, Sick Days are great

Fred Smith knows what he's doing.  He has based FedEx on the People-Service-Profit premise that if you take care of your people, they will provide the service needed and the profit will come.  He actually wants to take care of his employees and customers.
cons: To move far up the ladder, you'll have to live in Memphis, TN at some point. And if you're from a big city environment, or like having lots of cultural things to do, you probably won't be thrilled to live there. However, if you tend to throw your life into your work, then that might be a good thing because you won't have many distractions (if you're from a small town or like a slower pace of life, it's perfect). The company is also conservative, bureacratic, methodical, and tends to move slow. If you are used to fast-paced, wheeling and dealing companies where you don't need multiple levels of approvals for things, then this might not be for you.
Long hours worked and wear and tear on body. High expectations

Shift work in certain positions that can be very disruptive to healthy sleep. No time off during "Peak" season. Generally Dec 1, through Dec 26.  Also when you have off for a Holiday,  generally scheduled to work much earlier the day after because freight is behind by a day. If you are young and looking for a career with security, growth and very fair wages,  FedEx is worth looking in to. Older people and disabled not so much.
No room for growth or very little
Poor communication for part time

- 3-4 People can NOT handle a store on their own--especially in a congested area. We never had enough people to work on the floor
- We were expected to print, ship, AND provide sales on the floor. We had to clean our own bathrooms and try to provide customer service to those who want to print things on their own. It's IMPOSSIBLE.
- I remember being opening a store with my assistant manager and having 15+ people needing our assistance. Again. That is IMPOSSIBLE because we also provide print services. So we will have these long lines because we're working with customers that would require 15+ minutes of our time to assist them. Then we go and have to ship things for other customers. THEN we have to handle angry customers because they're waiting 30+ minutes just to buy a notebook. It's ridiculous and stressful and just. Ugh. It has been three years since I set foot to work in a Fedex store and it STILL was traumatic. I cried driving up there one time it was that bad.
- I didn't have proper training but was expected to just "figure it out" when dealing with customers placing a print order.
- Think twice about working in the retail store; or just don't do it.

Very hard to be a remote employee in IT because it isn’t the norm in the dept I am in. I do understand that I have to work even harder to stay visible- but that also means my manager and team also needs to make sure they include me in communications and meetings. Kinda hard to be involved if I’m not being told what’s going on... but it’s still new to allow remotes, so I’m sure it will get better
Not all managers were honest and there is problems with favoritism.
Management ideas do not trickle down

Unfortunately, too many in management/senior management are more interested in their next promotion or how to obtain a 5-Star than they are in doing right things right the first time.  Fred's renewed emphasis on Quality is falling on deaf ears in the management and senior management ranks.  They are using the ready-fire-aim method rather than assess-build-launch-evaluate.

review: Ethical company poised for continued growth
Good benefits and work life balance
date_position: May 6, 2019 - Fed Ex Ground Package Handler
pros: Great pay for the area. I am very happy with how I am treated at FedEx. FedEx has a pension plan that is very nice. The pension plan is a portable pension plan, which means I keep it even if I leave the company; however, I have no plans to leave. The IT market in Memphis is very poor right now. I feel lucky to be at FedEx during such hard times. Hilton, Internation Paper, Service Master, and Harrah's Entertainment all seems to making big cut backs, including layoffs. It seems that the only IT jobs left in Memphis are contract jobs.

If you are willing to move to Memphis, there are lots of opportunities to grow your career.  The leadership team is made up of employees who grew through the ranks so they know the business intimately and can relate to employees. I really like the senior leadership team -- they are ethical and easy to talk to because they listen to you regardless of your position in the company.
The people you work with are laid back
Allowed Flexible Hours and days of week to work
Learn how to work hard
Great benefits and flexible hours
Good benefits and work life balance
Cool management and hectic vibe
It’s okay job  very low key

Im my honesty opinion i do love the company, I'm able to get my products before the delivery ( because i work there), shipping is Much Cheaper, great environment, management is understanding and willing to actually work with you in almost any situation thinkable, were always changing and updating things, food parties if we have a good week and since I'm still in school working at night is a god send because i have all day to myself. If you love to workout this place will give you a good workout. but the best thing about this place is that they choose workers for management before looking outside the company!!
cons: It is hard to make a name for yourself and stand out. Great pay for the area. I am very happy with how I am treated at FedEx. FedEx has a pension plan that is very nice. The pension plan is a portable pension plan, which means I keep it even if I leave the company; however, I have no plans to leave. The IT market in Memphis is very poor right now. I feel lucky to be at FedEx during such hard times. Hilton, Internation Paper, Service Master, and Harrah's Entertainment all seems to making big cut backs, including layoffs.

They are very slow to move sometimes and it feels like everything down the most minute internal memo requires legal review. There is a distinct "Memphis-centric" sense to the mid-level business partners - as though if you are out in the field, you need to prove yourself that much harder because they are skeptical that anybody else can do what they do.
the work load is intense
Unsupportive management and training advancement structure
No appreciation for hard work
Sometimes weather can be hard to adjust
Career advancement is difficult.
Not flexible and super tiring
Not really good to  Employees

probably could be a bit better pay for certain situations ( taking on multiple rolls in the company like me), and making the environment a little more fun i guess you could say (more so making the workers feel better as they work)

review: Decent company but leadership & resources lacking
FedEx services- challenging job with the potential for earnings
One of Memphis' best employers, rated in the top 100 places to work in IT
pros: It is the largest customs brokerage, decent hours, interesting projects.
There is a good Work life balance, culture
Great earnings potential, Sales Professionals have one of the top jobs within the Corporation.
Can't really think of any.
You get a check every week.
Good benefits and decent pay

I love the work. It's like getting paid to exercise. After you hit 1,000 hours, you qualify for very inexpensive, very awesome health, vision and dental benefits. After 3 months of employment you have access to PTO, which is pretty great. It's very laid back in terms of work attire (you can basically wear anything you'd like) and I like that it's kind of a "locker room" environment in the hub. No one is going to bat an eye if you drop the F bomb. Lol.
co-workers are great, immediate management is good, health benefits are good for a family

10 years ago FedEx was a place I was proud to contract trucks with.  It WAS a fun place to work.  The memory includes decent pay, a tire discount program, a maintenance program with bonuses.  and a decent run schedule.
Company has really good benefits
cons: Leadership is lacking.  Do not get most federal holidays off.  Good old boy network.
Favoritism, if you're manager isn't good you will struggle
Tremendous responsibility to your customers and the company. Change is Constant.

The worst company I have ever had the displeasure of working for! The nepotism and cronyism are so vapid, that promotions, advancing to other departments are non-existent. People abuse 'working from home' and 'traveling' they never have to use their vacation days, because all they have to say is that they are WFH. Meanwhile, the people who are doing most all the grunt work are required to sit there from 9-6 watching others come and go as they please (example: they come in at 10am and leave around 2pm and yes, they take a lunch too). If someone is ever so privileged to have the title "manager" they get to do even less. Zero communication, which leads to constant chaos and stress. No dress code, people often dress like it is a Friday night club. Zero professionalism all around. When corporate comes to visit, they send emails (to about half of the company) telling them to dress up and show up to work. The company was started by some frat brothers so you can imagine the atmosphere. People walk around the office with their speakerphones on, other times they yell at each other (carry conversations) across the room rather than get up and talk or email. Some departments are grossly underpaid, meanwhile, new hires (friends and family) get a hefty payday. The building is disgusting nasty stains all over the carpet.
Management treats you like your in the milltary...weekend work assigned at last minute, you cannot plan a single weekend, because you never know if your working. Poor Managment!!!!!!
Hours were unpredictable and were forced to do different positions without much training

Not a very liveable wage, and outside of peak season the hours can be very meager and inconsistent. If they have to many people and not enough packages, they start sending people home early for the shift/sort. It can be very hard on the body, very dangerous and rigorous.

salary is lower here than other parts of the country due to a bit lower cost of living, benefits are slowly being chipped away at, some subtle, traditional pension no longer offered, first ever pay cut in 2008 of 5% (more counting no bonus and no 401K matching that was stopped for a while) never restored despite better company performance a few years later.  jumpseat flying taken away.  parts of the city and some surrounding suburbs are going downhill as the city annexes more areas

Every year the FedEx  contract has taken from us.  We were forced to put workers comp on contracted drivers. FedEx never gave us revenue to cover this cost.  We were forced to make contracted drivers OUR employees.  FedEx didn't compensate us for the additional costs. The tire program was cancelled, The maintenance program with bonuses was cancelled.  I'm sure the fuel cards, fuel tax program and toll transponders are the next to go.  
  If you have an accident FedEx Ground will almost always say it was your fault.  Even if it goes to court and you win.  I've seen this happen.
   One of the drivers had prostrate cancer.  FedEx tried to disqualify him after his doctor ok'd him to return to work.  He's back to work but only after FedEx Ground was threatened with a law suit.   Local management is an embarrassment and disgrace..
Not much to grow in the tech support department

review: Overall, working with the IT group was a miserable experience. Company overall is very good.
Not Bad! Easy to get job!
pros: Good compensation and great work life balance.

The brand is second to none, the service is second to none and the employees are second to none.  Our customer are top priority from the janitors to the CEO.  We all share the same vision and as a result we are able to focus on our customers.  I would be willing to bet that if asked every single employee could tell you what their purpose is and why.  I would also be willing to be that the answer would always end with a customer driven purpose.  We know why we are here.  It isnt about us.

You get to become connected with the business community and go behind the scenes to see what goes on in the warehouse, on the dock, manufacturing areas, production, etc.  Very fascinating stuff goes on behind otherwise normal looking front doors.

Good Health insurance coverage and price. About $400/mo for Kaiser, dental and vision for family coverage.
Pretty good compensation for the work.  Chances for advancement, if you have a flexible schedule.  Ability to transfer to different locations.  Advancement seems to have slowed down, due to FedEx being a mature company, and slowing of business.  There do seem to be a lot of people that have been there 20-25 years, so there may be better chances of advancement in the near future.  Good place for people without a degree to make an okay living.  Good for people looking for part-time and benefits.  Company has matching 401k and pension plan.
The company overall is very generous. Benefits were great. Everyone I worked for was great and very helpful. Company has a great reputation both inside and outside
Benefits are good, pay not so much.
Non waste of time

Easy Application, Quickly hired you after observation and fill the application, All of you will get hired no matter what if you have experience or not but important that you have a transportation to work from home. Flexible with schedule or you can arrive late but you must call advance one hour prior work start! Awesome!

The work is quite simple most of the time. You get to set your own pace, work as hard as you want and finish early; or take your time and cruise through the day. It really depends on the location, or the boss you work for, but most of the time, the workload is fairly reasonable. Also, most of the actual job takes place outdoor, so that can be a positive or negative depends on the person. The pay was fair for the work involved, and most of the time the equipment are well maintained and suited for the job. The job also doesn't demand much of customer interaction if you're not comfortable doing that kind of things.
Easy work, kind of like a work out really
cons: Middle management does not have a clear vision

It is a very long day. When you strive for perfection which the company and the employees do there are frustrating moments when something goes wrong.  Weather, technology blips.  We dont want unsatified customers.  We are in the business of delivering packages not bad news.  We have long days because we want the customer to be able to go home on time.
Enormous bureaucracy  - it's very difficult to make progress.  No career progression unless you want to move to Memphis.

Can be difficult scheduling vacations, days off.  Having to work holidays. Varied schedule.  Vacations needs to be scheduled a year in advance and taken in 5 day blocks, which makes it difficult to schedule days off if you have kids involved in activities you want to go to.  Time off is based on availability and seniority.

The department I worked for under the IT group (specifically the QA Department) was less than desirable. Uncertainty on my job role & function, micromanaging and the inability to move out from under the SVP made life miserable. I was hired in by a manager who was new and didn't know what his role was nor did he know exactly what my role was. The result was a 'sink or swim' environment that resulted in being in survival mode in the world of a monster company. I will never forget what it means to be in 'the belly of the beast' working for this company.
Poor pay, high work load, highly political and volatile environment.
pushing to hard to pick up packages, violating speed limits, and parking laws

Last minutes to informs you the schedule to start work, Manager will yelled at you daily, push you to rush & work hardest.  Hell to work! Because you will have to pick up 0.01 lbs- 150lbs or more.  Very strict with tardy and absent if you do. Possible to get termination or ask you resign.

The workload is very erratic, there's almost never a normal workday; especially around the holidays. The time you start actually working depends very much on the people who work in the office and handle your paperwork. A majority of time, you will be working by yourself, so if you run into any problem, it's usually all up to you to solve it.
Depending on the volume hours can range from 2-4

review: Could be a great job if you know what you are getting in to...
Great place overall but is becoming too slow to react and very resistant to change.
Small fish in a very big pond... you are just a number here.
If you like to keep your head down this is a good place.
Great job but not for everybody.
pros: people, freedom, no boss, work at your own pace
Nothing no advancement long morning meetings
In sales, there is a relative sense of job security even when you are not that good.  There are nice benefits like car stipends and insurance.
Pay is pretty good I'd say
Very good life/work balance, good benefits and interesting work.
There are some and always have been some great people that work at this company. I have built some long and lasting relationships with many of them.
Good pay, Overtime, benefits, paid time off

The benefits are pretty good compared to other companies.  The insurance is good.  The pension has been changed twice in the last five years, but at least we have one.  If you are in the field you have a great opportunity to satisfy your customers.  You can build relationships and run your job like it is your own business.  There is a no layoff policy, although it is not written in stone.  The senior mgmnt. is invisible to people in the field.  There is no one looking over your shoulder when you do your job.  If you are a courier you are outside most of the time.

Job stability -- very difficult to lose one's job here.
401(k) employer match is decent.
Health insurance was ok, getting worse with consumer health plan in '14
If you work in a well-managed port, things can be really great.

When I got this job it was simply a part-time job to make ends meet right after I had my wife had our first child. With that being said, it was a great job and if you are a hard worker that shows up on time you are definitely appreciated and provided with ample opportunity to move up within the company, probably more so than any place I have ever worked.
cons: hours, pay, no benefits, management
Short hours miserable staff and coworkers

If you really want to succeed you simply must become like those above you.  While they may say they want people who "think-outside-the-box" I really don't think they really understand what that means.  Senior management in the -+55 age range are stifling growth and causing real talent to leave.  They would rather you go through the formalities and become a box checker as opposed to questioning why things are done how they are.  They are building the future based on the ideas of the past that have succeeded with no variation for today's world.  Middle management lacks any real backbone when it comes to allowing senior management to understand what is really going on.  You can come in as a great thinker with great ideas but you will soon see others getting promoted simply because they are more like the person above them.  The performance review is really somewhat of a joke.
Tough work. Lots of things to do

FedEx is no longer a young company but it has not yet learned how to deal with its age. Most decisions are still made very high up. It becomes increasingly difficult to acomplish anything due to lots of red tape and bureaucracy behind which a lot of incompetent MDs and VPs are hiding. Worse, very rarely anyone is punished for poor performance or failed projects. All that makes promotions slow and a lot of great people leave due to lack of opportunities.

For more than a decade this company has had a high rate of turnover and their management is well compensated when their employees are downsized and given pay cuts. The company has a good year and employees dont get a bonus and have even received pay cuts. This company goes through predictable cycles of a few good years and then a few bad years revenue wise. The troubles all come from management - they are arrogant and not focused. They tell you how important the culture is at this company but they are telling you this from their rather large ivory towers.

Don't be fooled this company has no loyalty to you... 99% of the 30+ people I know that used to work there have moved on to better jobs elsewhere with more pay and more opportunity. While 99% of the people I know that still work there are in the same jobs or only made lateral moves or one bump in position. Good place to just collect a paycheck that will never change.
Hostile environment, favoritism, extra heavy workload, very stressful

This is a two tiered company.  Management vs. hourlies.  The frontline employees are viewed with utter contempt.  The managers micromanage everything.   The managers are kool-aid drinkers and many believe anything upper management tells them even when it makes no sense.  The benefits have slowly been whittled away from us.  No more profit sharing, no jumpseat benefit, no survivor income benefit, no Individual performance pay.  If you have surgery and go out on disability you get five sick pay days and then you have to go on STD. The vendor for Fedex treats you like a criminal.  Fedex chooses the low cost provider for benefits.

Too fragmented and different modes don't speak the same language.
Some managers are too divorced from operations and make odd or silly decisions.
HR is out to lunch and some egregious employee behavior is not addressed timely.
Job descriptions don't match actual duties resulting in underpaid and overworked staff.
Compensation is too low for the level of knowledge required to do most jobs.
Training is not a priority despite the increasing demand for compliance by CBP, lots of out of pocket expenses to get the training needed to advance.
Antiquated computer systems - 20 yrs is too long to go without a major update.

I said that it was a great job, and it is, but it certainly isn't for everyone. I was a part-time package handler and I was offered a full-time position fairly quickly. As a package handler you load or unload trucks, that are dusty as all get out, it hot and cold environments, depending on the season. The dust probably bothered me more than the heat, I'd come home and blow black snot out of my nose on a regular basis. Still a good job though.

review: Great if You Live in memphis
Excellent, great company to work for
I was a package handler and I loved it!
5 years in - Great Company, Antiquated Policies
pros: Independent work, time goes by fast, pension, insurance benefits, tuition reimbursement, can transfer anywhere in the country, lots of internal jobs to transfer into, great for a college student because of the 2nd shift jobs and tuition reimbursement.

Due to its long term success and market leadership the company is overall hesitant to change out of a fear that the tech is too complicated modify. For the right professional this is an excellent business  opportunity to innovate. The core business satisfies a basic public need, and the business is simple in that it is about delivering a package as quickly as possible whether its a letter or shamu the whale
Good benefits and good hours
Very Physical.  You'll stay in shape.  part time and seasonal

Good healthcare and benefits. Relatively good job security as long as you do your job at a half competent level (i.e. they don't really fire anyone). Good willingness to embrace a healthy work-life balance.

Focus on people, work/life balance, opportunities to rotate and grow, hire/promote from within, healthy team environment in most teams I have seen, good benefits, strong/stable company, very well managed (which  I particulatly saw during the 2009 economic downturn), people's opinions are sought and taken into consideration by leadership (anonymous employee surveys), opportunity for one to get stand by plane tickets (since FedEx is an airline), among many other reasons.
Become a strong individual.
good pay good benefits for job.

I was a casual package handler and loved it! Casual handler was a no benefits position, but if you stayed around long enough then you could get a Permanent Part-Time position that would include benefits. It was a great part-time job and it even had benefits available for working just 17 hours. It was fast paced, but I worked closely with other employees and developed good relationships with many employees in a short amount of time. I would definetely recommend this job to anyone looking for a supplemental part-time job.

- Low Stress Environment: nobody's competing or trying to steal your job
- Job Security: there is very little fear of being fired for being incompetent at a task. At worse, you fail and raise some gossip behind your back
- Work/Life Balance: depending on your team, sometimes you can go missing for days (unannounced) and nobody really bats an eye - benefit of the doubt, but don't push it
cons: At the courier level, the job is only as good as the management. Most of the managers I have worked for have been extremely unprofessional. I suspect they are being asked to do impossible tasks, and it seems most of them can't handle the pressure when they pass on their requirements to the couriers. The managers are rude, impossible, inflexible, revengeful, and play favorites to the point where it makes the job not worth working there. Upper management does not deal with unprofessional management at the operations level effectively. Inept managers are allowed to retain their job for decades rather than remedial training, or termination. New employees who are hired as couriers will never make what I make now because fedEx has implemented a two-tier wage system. It's impossible for a new hire to ever top out. Only lip service is paid to improving the work process and environment through employee input. employees are simply told what to do whether the command has been thought through thoroughly or not.

An understandable hesitation to change exists regardging working systems fro day operations. Even as there are aging technologies in some areas. the general managment attitude is a reluctancy to consider improvements due to complex embedded proprietary business methods
Cheap pay and not enough incentives
low pay. mediocre management.  unrealistic expectations

Management is hit or miss. Many of the managers seem to people who have just been around long enough that they've been promoted because they have the most seniority. Team building and incorporating remote workers into work groups is a challenge that is given LOTS of lip service, but no real support.

Company grew very quickly and very big over the last 10-20 years and it's different businesess are not that well integrated (watch out that your job is not limited to a small silo.) Growth in US has been leveling off so there are not as many promotion opportunities as it used to be. There are some though and it's overall a fantastic company to work for.
Bad upper management need to be more involved.
long physically demanding hours in climate

Due to the nature of the work, all handlers were required to work strict schedules. There is almost no schedule flexability at all, unless you were a Permanent Part-Time and used Personal Time Off. Other than that, I loved everything else about the job!

- Low Stress Environment: nobody wants to do any innovative or challenging work outside their job description
- Job Security: since no one thinks they can get fired, no one takes initiative on anything that doesn't come directly from their manager - and even then, challenging may ensue
- Pay Plateau: be wary and do the math first. Whatever salary you enter making will not change much over the course of time. Promotions are more time-based than merit, so it doesn't really matter if you do a great job or not...just do your time and you'll get there, 3% (yearly) or 7% (promotion) at a time. Until you hit your payband cap at least - then you're just stuck forever.

review: Good job if you have no asiprations other than a paycheck.  Those with ambition look elsewhere.
Enjoyed the people (co-workers and customers), the company did not involve the ops side of the business in decesions.
The worst place to work unless you like carrying others (Memphis employee reviews are happy as Springfield carries them)
FedEx:  High Employee Expectations Enhances Brand
Trustworthy company with good growth opportunities
Great work-life balance, Nice values, Nice people, Nice resources/technologies and a weak , redundant middle management
pros: Flexibility - Fedex is very casual and laid back.  Unless you work in dot-com or other critial business areas you'll work 40 hours or less a week.

Great benefits, however the benefits were not the same for FedEx Office as they were for the FedEx's parent company.  Training was good and on=going, both on=line and occasional classroom training.  Advancement opportunity was great, they truly promote from within.
They recognize you with gifts for years of service.
You have a steady source of income.
Always work to be done.

FedEx is a company that has high expectations for it's employees and is always striving for excellence.  This attitude is what enables the FedEx brand to be so well considered.  Salaries are fair and the benefits are terrific.  The fact that FedEx provides a pension for their employees demonstrates their commitment to their "People First" ideal.

FedEx's current CEO is the original founder of the company with great dreams. This is good because the company has not lost track any time and has been very successful. The management has shown integrity and effectiveness in the past 35 years of history and is one of the virtual duopolies in the US. In the current  economic turmoil FedEx has shown tremendous strength and resorted to salary cuts and downsizing in a seemingly  fair,  controlled and minimal  way.  The company provides good opportunities for advancement and compensation and advancement are generally performance based. I have not heard of any  discrimination based on race, sexual orientation etc. in this company. In short FedEx is a reliable company with good growth opportunities.
The benefits are nice here.

Solid Fair Company.  Great branding and visualization.  It is truly wonderful to come to work where people care about one another and enjoy working together for a greater purpose, which is to service the world.  FedEx helps the Economy and we definitely do our share of supporting outside causes such as United Way.  It was absolutely amazing at how many were willing to volunteer their time and efforts this past Christmas Day and never complained about it.  We just knew it had to be done.  It made me proud that when companies are dying out there from the soft economy that our leader, Fred Smith, stood up for his company and said instead of downsizing and layoffs, we are going to take a pay decrease from my salary on down.  That shows someone who cares.

-FedEx has a mostly great , non-flighty attitude towards it's employees. It focuses on timeless values of "respect" and "building stability "  versus "use-and-throw" !!

- Great work/life balance 

- Good resources/advanced technologies /advanced training opportunites in Marketing for professional development.

- Good ethnic diversity !

- Internal promotion
cons: Politics, micromanagement, meetings -  it depends on which area you work but getting ahead at FedEx is about who you know and who you network with at FedEx.  The secret to getting ahead at FedEx is to make it your life, bleed orange and purple, be on your blackberry 24/7/365 to your mgrs.  Excessive reporting on your activities.  Each month I have 2 meetings with my director on project updates, monthly dashboard updates, weekly timekeeping and weekly project meetings.  Anything less and you'll be branded a "cowboy" or not a team player.  More time is spent on how you do things vs. getting the work done.

On the FedEx Office side, FedEx did not involve the opeartions side in any decesions they rolled out that could affect their customers or co=workers.  Unrealistic goals were set for stores to achieve in the area of sales, again this is where involvement would be helpful.  Store management would have been able to offer information that should have been considered when setting budgets for their areas (local economy, competition, etc.).  Too much change, SOP's would change weekly, I would describe it a the spagetti test.  They would roll out a new policy or process and not wait long enough to test the process before changing it again (throw spagetti at a wall and not wait long enough to see if it would stick).  They lost credability with co-workers and made it difficult to manage and hold co-workers accountable with the constant changes.
No room for advancement. Pay is not good.
You work long hours with little recognition.

- Excessive overtime that is mandatory.
- Required to "assist" others to get their work done.  No self accountability, and this only applies to the favorites.
- Favoritism.
- Next to no room for advancement.
- Wages are about 20 years behind.  In no way competitive for the responsibility and knowledge required for the position.
- GM only supports the growth of people like her, and if you are any different she will ensure you do not advance and your get nickel and penny raises.  The worst in favoritism.  She fires people for not doing things that even she cannot handle in her position.
- New hires get hired on for more than tenored staff makes after 10+ years of service.
- The office is much like high school and has lots of cliques.  If you aren't "popular" people will treat you bad.
- Mistreatment by other employees will never be addressed by management. Despite all the politically correct information in the handbook, they will allow other employees to bully individuals.  
- Your family and personal life must come last.  Unless again you are part of the popular crowd, then you are allowed long lunches to go shopping.

Too many performance metrics makes it almost impossible to get a perfect report card and can become distracting to performing the job at hand.  Lot's of time is involved outside of the office.  FedEx is not the place for a person who is only willing to work 40 hours a week.
There is some red-tape and  it is probably because of the size of the company. The company is conservative and hence chances for innovation are not too many.
The people can be sometimes mean.
It is so competitive that it is hard at times to move ahead professionally speaking.

- Weak, incompetent middle managers who were plain lucky to get promoted during the need time in early 2000.Not much leadership skills or intellectual abilities seen.

- Promotions can be based on a personal liking versus a collective / objective one.

- Rules, privileges ( such a remote working permisiion) changes from group-to-group ! Some are more equal than others.

review: A job to pay the bills
Good company but the halo is questionable.
Undervalued, monotonous work with okay benefits
date_position: Jun 17, 2017 - Operations Manager/Account Executive/Quality Assurance Manager
pros: It's a good, physical job that is rewarding when you step back and see how much you do in a day. Every day is different, with changing challenges and new experiences. The company always hires from within so if you're willing to work hard and climb the ladder this is a great opportunity.

Integrity of executive leadership
People Service Profit culture and respect of persons
Some working flexibility
Great people to work with!  Good work/life balance if you know how to manage your time.  Just do your work and you will ahve a place to work for a long time.

Perks are great. You get about 5 raises the first year. Very flexible schedule, you work Monday thru Friday but if you need a day off your manager has your back. Fun if youre with the right people. SUPER EAZY TO GET INTO THE JOB. We get free food all the time and t-shirts!
Work load isn't much, great for student
401k matching and affordable insurance.

Great benefits and if you do your job (not even well) you can count on staying employed.  The salary is competitive and the company is good at what it does.

Many good managers - great work-life balance.  They really do care about their staff.
Great Exposure to many Companies with instant credibility to get in and help them growth their business with logistics consulting.  Anyone who has the right attitude at this company will succeed.

The training is nice, but depending on the department you are going to, could be completely useless.
Co-workers generally nice and helpful, though you may get in trouble for asking them questions on the floor, as management theory is that no one knows what they're doing.
3 weeks vacation, 10 sick and 6 floating holidays. When those benefits start depend on your hire month. You can go maybe 6 months without vacation, depending on your start date, but that is pretty normal.

People based company.  Train well and let people make their own decisions and don't micromanage.  Excellent training and they ensure that you understand your responsibilities well.  Remove obstacles from employees so they are free and willing to go above and beyond for the customer
cons: The hours will destroy your social life. Although it's normal for a salary position to work more then forty hours a week it's when the hours happen during the day that is the killer. My current position is from 1 P.M.-10 P.M. Mon-Fri so forget going out at night with spouse, family or friends during the week and doing all of your errands in the morning. The other option is from 10 P.M.-6 A.M. which may give you the better part of your evening back but it takes a certain type of person to do a job this physical on a third shift schedule.

Very difficult to advance and grow, many people are frustrated. Structure internal interview process favors those who learn the process over merit and ability. Little incentive to move laterally results in in-breeding in many - not all - departments.
Push to broaden management span has decreased management opportunities.
Executive leadership has had a history of putting profit above people while stating the opposite. Promised bonus has not been paid at  100% for over ten years. No visibility into the bonus process despite the CFO's video communications, which only results in further questions. 
People Service Profit culture is lip service with many vps, directors, and managers.
Remote working opportunities have been restricted.
Many aspects of the culture and working environment are stuck in the 80s and 90s,
Nepotism - the chairman's son started at a hard-to-get principal position and is the fastest-rising executive  with apparently no competition for positions.

Typical corporate jibberish.  What salesforce hears from upper managerment during the rah rah sessions (middle mgt excluded) and what middle mgt is told and does is usually quite different.  I was located in AZ and the closest HR rep is 1200+ at Corp.  That can make for some interesting situations and lack of HR support.  Most of us felt like we had no advocate.

If you do the math...the amount of hours + the amount of pay + plus the amount of physical labor you do = not worth it for me. I'm 5'2 and weigh a little of 100lbs. And I've been doing this job for the past 3 months, and I've done really good. Except for I'm broke and I can't wear shorts because I'm covered in bruises and people think I get abused at home. It's a decent in between jobs job. also, it might be easy to move up but you can't apply for another position until you've been there for at least 6 months. They make it out to be your fault if you get injured on the job but will throw a fit if you don't report it.
Pressure, lack of management
minimal advancement opportunities.  unorganized. unprofessional. no incentive to work to full potential.  insufficient training.

There are a lot of old timers (20+ yrs) that won't quit - no matter how many buy outs are offered.  This is a constant frustration since there is little focus put on getting ahead of the competition in the digital arena.  Many middle management are stone walls for progress and are overly concerned with (outdated) process adherence and internal metrics that only impact year end internal goals - not based on progress in the market.  There are some GREAT managers - but a bad managing director can and often will skunk up the teams beneath them.  

More meetings than are needed and far too many obstacles to innovation.

If you like a fast pace and modern tech - you need to look into the marketing team - the Services/TechConnect side will only frustrate you.
It is So Fun & Exciting  it is Hard to balance Work & Life at Home.

Work is monotonous, as is most data entry, can't say it wasn't expected.
Stressful to be both efficient (lots of files processed) and accurate (zero mistakes, even human error typos count against you).
Little room for career advancement.
Monthly reviews are meant to be helpful but come across as either punishment or an excuse to pile on extra work if you perform well for no extra benefits.

Growing too quickly.  Acquired ground and companies split rather than remaining one solidified company.  It works well for specialization in certain areas, but leaves employees not having a well rounded understanding of everything the company has to offer the customer.

review: Being the best is hard work!
Work is fast paced, managers are cool, little hours, good pay.
pros: You can make decent money but is it worth your sanity.
Quite a diverse array of people from all backgrounds. Pretty flexible with people's schedules.
It is a good company with excellent benefits.

FedEx is a great place to work! Everyone here works for a common goal "To make a customer experience outstanding" via the FedEx Purple Promise.  Also, there's so many opportunities to grow in the company. I've been employed here for 2 years and 11 months and have been promoted 3 times.  The opportunities are endless, you just have to put yourself out there and strive to be the best becasue you are representing the best.
Very employee friendly. You will get to work with a very smart, highly efficient set of co-workers without a cut-throat environment.

Benefits, Fed Ex pays at most a weeks vacation. If you are a student you have the opportunity to apply for tuition reimbursement, but you must be passing classes. 
Managers are understanding and are cool if you ask for a day off, like most jobs though you can't be missing too much days.

Something is always screwed up, so even part-timers can usually get all the hours they want. If you like to keep moving all day this job is for you. The medical benefits are crap now, but that's not peculiar to FedEx. Even part-time hires immediately get the same medical as everyone else.
