My only complaint has been of management lately at my facility. Someone was hired based on who they were and not what they knew. Now morale is down at our facility from being micromanaged by someone who does not really know what is going on.

review: The worst experience in my life
It could be worse, but it could always be better
The place to work in Memphis
Solid company- they expect you to want to build a career there.
Better employer than most, old-style management
Great benefits....the people policy is declining.
pros: pride in the brand, benefits are good especially travel perks; should be more to say but cant really think of anything else; tuition reimbursement is great
The company have Good Benefits

FedEx has the ability to pull up its bootstraps when times get difficult.  I have seen management continually cut costs, thus ensuring the workforce is spared from layoffs.  In a time when job security is somewhat scarce, FedEx has continually offered its workforce a safe haven as long as packages keep shipping.  I believe this is a testament to the overall management by our founder Fred Smith.  As long as he is around, I really do believe the employees will be thought about before drastic cuts are made.

Every employee is treated as a vital and valued part of the organization. 
Outstanding opportunity for advancement and career development even for people lacking a college degree or traditional education.
Training readily available for carrer development.  
Company culture values military veterans and the experience gained in service to the military.
Very good benefits, even for part time and non-exempt employees. 
Company is a steward to the community and encourages employees to follow the example
Stability- you won't make a mint but you can be pretty certain if you do your job you will continue to have one.  Good organizational culture with a sense of humor.  There are some people
Good benefits, good perks, one of the few companies that still have pensions, good bonuses

You are virtually your own boss as far as daily work is concerned.  Once you become familiar with your route you will have a shorter work day for the same pay.  If you are interested in advancing within the company , it is ground level and could be used as a spring-board into other positions.  It's a steady job.
Good pay, good benefits. Extensive training. Holiday pay, sick pay, vacation pay, and floating as need off pay days. Opportunity for advancement and transfers. Free air travel.
Good benifits. 401k. Pension. Non Union. Medical,  Dental, Vision available.  Most employees great people. They just want to do their job and go home to family.
They make sure their employees are well taken care of. You work alone, the shifts are short. No micromanagement and the managers are laid back and easy going.
cons: too metrics focused. not focused enough on the people; constant pressure to do more and they don't seem to value experience anymore. very focused on new people. definitely not interested in using the right people for the right jobs. continuing to downsize through attrition just to hide what you are doing is not working. Pressuring people by having them do 3 and 4 people's job is wrong.

No Managerial support including human resources - Every departments have clicks and if you are not part of it, you will be cast as an outsider.  Most of the employees have been there    10 - 30 yrs, started in the hub or another lower paid position and think FedEx is the best job in the world. They feel if someone is hired from the outside, that person has not put there work in for the company; so the chances of advancement or slim to none  In addition, if management doesn't like you, they will falsify annual reviews, give inaccurate letters of warnings to make it look like an employee is not performing well, which are lies.   Also, managers are allowed to manage friends, so if you think about complaining, you better think twice and have you another job already lined up.  Pathetic!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

There are a lot of "old guard" employees left at FedEx.  The same benefit that FedEx has in providing a safe haven for its employees, also leads to a bit of a downfall in unqualified workers.  In the IT arena where I work, there are many folks still on the job, whether having moved to a new department or not, whose time had come many years ago.  Unfortunately, it seems neither they nor management has seen it that way.  It leads to discourse in some of the younger and hungrier employees who share the same titles as the older ones, but end up performing most of the work.  These "old-timers", whose vacation times now exceed 5 weeks in some cases, come and go as they please, and are allowed to reap the same benefits and titles as those of us with much more aptitude for the job.  This can be very discouraging and cause a lot of qualified folks to turn away from working at FedEx.

Expect to work hard in the sort facility. It is tough work but strong teams are built to handle it. 
24/7/365 operation. Expect long hours and little time off in the Holiday rush.
Lots of internal barriers to promotion and movement- some cultural some legal.  Things take time, and it can be difficult to see results from your work in the short term.
Old-style management, emphasis on seniority, sometimes challenging to move up, non-union, H/R is elusive to employees by design, no open-door policy

Some work days are never-endingly long.  Holidays are a time when this will absolutely be the case.  Weather and other driving irratations are part of the everyday worklife of this position.  Fellow co-workers with negative/whiny attitudes can be an issue.  Be aware you will likely be underpaid as you will be a sub-contractor.

Upper management has begun to micromanage since 2008. This has resulted in less teamwork and more focus on individual performance. Work hours can be long and there's very little flexibility to take time off in emergency situations...sick child, etc. You have to bid on vacation time once a year, senior employees get first choice leaving crappy options for newer employes.

Pay increases should be on performance not years of service. How well you are treated comes down to your manager. Some senior managers are abusive and will use a willing manager to make all of the employees lives miserable and no one above will help if the numbers are good. Yes. They knew.

The work is a little fast paced. It's not an easy job, but it's more of you having to get use to lifting heavy boxes and playing tetris. It gets really hot in the trailers and the pay is worth it. Not that many people to talk to.

review: I Feel Very Lucky To Work For FedEx!!!! Great Company!!!!
As honestly as I can put it.
Be on the good side of your superiors.  This will open opportunities down the road.
12 years as a swing courier has been a constantly evolving experience.
Great company to work for as a pilot
FedEx is resting on its laurals, but is still a go company to work for.
pros: Good people work there. It’s a growing company in a growing industry, and there are opportunities.

Competitive Pay, Great Benefits, Great Opportunities Domestically and Globally, Selling the FedEx Brand, Job Security, Great Work Environment, Great Training and the way that your treated and coached by management (Developmental, Supportive, Fair and Objective)
Every day is the same, yet different. Once you leave the building you can sucessfully manage yourself. Great at working with communities and charities. Your success is what you make of it.

Working at FedEx provided very decent wages. The company benefits allowed my girlfriend to give birth and choose which hospital to have our first child with all the advantages of prenatal care and provided "lifeworks" nurse.
Nice people do work here

Company that allows growth, and easy to move up in the company. Have learned that your experience will greatly depend on your senior manager. Easy to transfer, or move to a different location and have a job. Benefits. better pay than retail. Get to be on the move. More often than not, management started same place as you.
benefits,  tuition reimbursement.  Great part time job for students.

No chance to get bored at this job! Good pay and benefits. Physically demanding, so less time at the gym. No layoff policy (even throughout the recession). Many opportunities for career advancement and able to transfer anywhere in the world if there is a position open.

Excellent pay and benefits for the industry. Stable, no furloughs in the history of the company, as far as pilots go. First class operation, airplanes are well maintained, flight safety is top priority. Tremendous amount of flexibility for this kind of job, as far as how much you desire to work.

FedEx still has many of the benefits that other companies have thrown away, although not as "rich" as they use to be.  FedEx Express has never laid off an employee.  FedEx promotes very largely from within.  FedEx treates customers much better than others in industry and therefore has a brand that gives an employee clout.  Most employees get along with each other and work together.
cons: Too many to list all: Inadequate, outdated, poorly kept, and run down resources. When your competition runs a business better than the very one you started-You know it’s bad. Company founded by a marine corps pilot=company run like its the military-assignments with tons of responsibility-yet no, limited, or poor resources provided to get the job done.  Employees are expected to use personal cell phone as a job aid, yet the company offers no reimbursement for the use of a personal item for company business. Heath insurance is the worst. Provider is Cigna, which is also the worst. Vision is Davis Vision, again the worst-you’re better off going to drug store glasses-less brain damage.  Package cars are filthy. Drivers leave food in them and the rats come in the middle of the night and eat it. I’ve seen droppings in the trucks.

Working with individuals who don’t appreciate the company or who do not want to pull their weight. Negative people always bring me down. However, for the most part all of the Account Executives I work with are exceptional and very professional. But like every company/sales department there are always individuals who struggle and are negative because of it.

You're required to load your own truck so you leave the station and greet the public sweaty and nasty. Benefits became much more expensive. You're punished if you do well by getting your delivery stops per hour (SPH) raised. You're forced to speed in order to meet your daily SPH avg. You are a human resource: If you get hurt and can't work you're discarded like a bent paper clip. Management is never satisfied with ANY results, good or bad. Couriers and lower management turnover is very high. Management is verbally abusive at times. There is no work/life balance unless you fight for it. It can be a very high pressured job.

I have experienced unfair treatment that included several years of fighting for upgrade of my job title/status along with a pay raise accordingly. Workload distribution amongst team members was also problematic, with longer tenured employees choosing the easiest job duties with the "grunt work" assigned to the new/junior employees and still receiving comparable pay raises. All time off is scheduled on seniority basis which at times affords the longest tenured employees all the holidays and/or prime summer vacation weeks and leaves the new employees with families and kids the unappealing weeks.

Management has drastically changed in the last 5 years.   Fedex is no longer a company designed to take care of its employees.   They have fully endorsed moving jobs offshore regardless of performance or language ability of the contractors and have now in their new building for the DFW area shows how little they care about employees by putting in an open cube system designed to remove privacy and end any self worth of an employees that remains.   Fedex is now showing they could care less about their employees by refusing to allow hires of anyone but foreign contractors who cannot do the job forcing the rest of us to do their work on top of our own and open desk designs telling every employee that you are no longer an individual.   You are just a number to them.
Your experience depends on management, if you don't like the company it's probably their faught and best just to transfer elsewhere.
If you're out of shape, this will suck for the first month.   It does get a lot easier the longer you're there.
Sometimes long hours and Saturday work required. Physically demanding. Productivity expectations are sometimes unreasonable. Fast pace and covering different areas is not for everyone.

Much of our flying is at night, which is very difficult on your body. Possible exposure to hazardous goods in a confined area. Don't know if they ever clean out the oxygen system for the masks, which could make you sick. These issues make me concerned about getting cancer.

There is the "FedEx way" and the wrong way.  This manifests itself in Purple-Correct thinking.  The company doesn't take serious ideas that come from "outsiders" who are hired.  Your opinion is valued inverse proportially to the number of digits in your employee number.  Except for Fred Smith, no one above the rank of Sr. VP understands the airline part of the company, so airline type issues do not get priority except in the view of eliminating cost.  Also, since the company has never laid off any workers, there are a lot of dead weight leeches entrenched inside the company.  Lot of people doing their nails in their cubes and taking 20 minute smoke breaks each hour.

Finally, if the company's salary exempt pay structure is near immoral.  No adjustment for cost of living.  Merit increases cap at 3.5% for a 4.0 employee.  This causes talented employees to leave while the leaches stay on.

review: Just  my observation - but shared by so many grunts who bleed purple.
I loved the job except numbers were more important that customer service.
Great place to work for people whp are not high acheivers
Great benefits for part time work
pros: Flex Time and Bonuses were good.  But the greatest reason to work for FedEx is the people (non-management).  They are the most down earth set of people you could work with.
There is minimal effort required to keep your job. There is almost no pressure to work more than 40 hours a week, and your peers are not generally terribly competitive.

You can interact with different people everyday.  You are in your own truck all day without supervision most of the time.  You get a good workout while you work.  Time passes quickly because your always running to meet deadlines.  I never got bored because your too busy.  I got satisfaction by helping my customers. Pay and benefits were excellent.
Great company, believe in People, Service, and Profits.. In the order. Very active in the local community and throughout the world, I am proud too say that I worked for FedEx.
Great Company to work for flexalbe hours good pay with no experience I've only been working with the company over 3 months but I hope to grow with this company.

The fedex health benefits are fantastic and is one of the two reasons I stay with the company because they offer fulltime benefits to part time employees like me. The 2nd reason I stay with the company is to be able to transfer to other states with the company and work and live in a new place.

Work/Life balance You can work from home, come late, leave early, go to the doctor without wasting vacation
What it does for the community
Diversity
Perks
Benefits
Job Security
Fun place to work
People
Health benefits for part time employees.  The pay is comparable to competitors such as UPS.  Stable company with great brand recognition.
Loved my job for most of the 23 yrs I was there. It used to be a family now its not anymore. I was a Courier. Loved my customers.

Gym / workout facility
Popcorn/coffee
March of Dimes campaign
cons:
FedEx's Low Level Managment to the CIO lack vision and direction, despite management's propaganda.  Many of FedEx Services problems are the reflection of the leadership in the management chain.  It's not what you know but who you know.  But this mantra has caught up to FedEx as it eventually catches up to most companies.  Middle management is more concerned with climbing up the corporate chain than doing what is right for the company, the stockholders, or the employees.  The Executive Management is so out of touch with was occurring at FedEx Services because they rely on middle management to be concise, ethical, and to the point.  However, as most work places including FedEx Services, middle management tells senior management what they want to hear rather than tell them how it really is. 

If you don't believe my commentary.  Ask a FedEx Services employee how successful 6x6 or 6x6 Reloaded was/is (off the record) in Memphis, Dallas, Colorado Springs, and Orlando?  For the brave souls who bleed purple will tell you it was/is a joke.  The biggest joke is the CIO, the Senior Vice Presidents, and the Vice Presidents, the most useless executives that the FedEx subsidiary could have assembled.  This management team should be dismantled and rebuilt.   Managing Directors and Managers should be terminated for three consecutive poor Pulse Survey Reviews.

My respect lies with the Chief Executive Officer like Fred W. Smith and Chief Financial Officer (CFO) Alan Graf and the grunts (Software Developers, Network Operations, Technical Writers, Networking Groups) within FedEx Services.  Everyone else is expendable.

Very little room for professional achievement / advancement unless you are interested in management or a facsimile thereof. There are a few ("advisor") positions which might have been used for technical advancement, but as managers have been free to simply offload their own duties onto those positions, they essentially become political junior management positions themselves.

There is too much micro management while your in the station unloading and loading the freight.  We were pressures do always do more with less people.  Too much paperwork and goal to meet in numbers on paper.  Getting 100% wasnt good enough.  Get written up for the smallest thing.  They had unreasonable expectations with delivery and pickup stops per hour.  without considering traffic or distance between stops.  Had to work over 12 hours a day but managment expected you to only put down 12 hours and not be paid because DOT laws.  Always had to work 10 to 12 hours without any break just to meet their unrealistic goals.  I was told to loose customers who were filling my truck up with freight and to replace them with 10 customers shipping 1 package because it made the managers numbers look better and they got bigger bonuses. They would promise us big bonuses to get us to work harder and faster and work thru breaks and on our own time but when the time came would make some excuse why the company couldn't pay it. They thought we should just be thankful to have the jib because other people don't,  But the managers would get 12,000 bonuses for our hard work.  If you got hurt they were out to get rid of you because they could lose some of their monthly bonuses. Managers showed too much favortism.

They have high level of expectations and  create some stressful situations. Also moving away from remote workers, while the rest of the world moves towards remote workers, FedEx is moving away from remote workers
It is not the cleanest environment It is very fast paste I don't feel like I have been trained enough to do my job.

Communication is terrible and getting help with different parts of the job is next to none from my manager. The pay is not the greatest either...very demanding and can be a high stress job. Must be able to be quick and multitask.

Some people have been there too long
Not innovative enough in some areas
There are some poor managers out there
Very slow to get things changed
Adoption of open source.
People & leadership development in IT

Managers lack training on how to effectively deal with employees.  Many of middle management has been with Fed Ex for a long time and may not have the best skills or managment tools, but a good grasp of the business.
They don't care about the people its all about the numbers and micro managing. Its very sad...If undercover boss ever came to a station they would be shocked. Its not the company it used to be :(

Work Life balance lie.  
50 - 75% outsourced development (India).
Complete accountability for failures (or successes) of a team 10 timezones away with a huge cultural/language barrier.

I was only there for three years.  The last 18 months were horrible.  My prior employment was 14 years with same company so I don't like to jump ship.  Our rather small team lost 11 employees in 9 months, some with over a decade at FedEx.  Two were asked to work another weekend and they unpinned their badges and left without notice.  I saw my manager and a Project Manager cry over the hours and abusive treatment of the team.  It's even worse for our Indian counterparts.  It was so bad I'd never ship with FedEx again if I have a choice.  Last, don't count on the bonuses they promise.  I found them to be much less than advertised but it's what they sell you on in the interview for their below industry average salary offering.

review: Worked as a package handler. Hot warehouse work but not difficult.
Could be a lot better, could be a lot worse....
Work life balance non existent for leadership
Be aware of working for Fedex,do your research. It's easy just stop a Fedex courier,on the street anytime,anywhere!
FedEx is a great company to work for.
pros: Instead of paying for a gym, work at a package warehouse and get an overall workout and get paid. Hours are short, 3 to 4 tops a day but there is always a chance to pick up another shift.
Friendly, quick and easy interview
Excellent company to work and some of the people there are very friendly and helpful and kind. The peoples that work at Fedex are team work and we help each other.  Good company to work for.

As a courier, if you put in some time, you might get a decent route. I do, and it gives me some flexibility, and I get off at a decent time most days. Managers pretty much leave you alone. Pay is not too bad. You won't get rich, but you can pay the bills.
Stable , People oriented company. i would recommed this company to other people who wants a stable and secure workplace. Not much pressure at work
Good stable company, good 401 k & vacation benefits. Company is always working hard at been the best in the market, adding services and technology.

Outstanding benefits, seasoned drivers understand new team members will require help to learn all the details to perform their duty and willingly do so no questions asked. Holiday seasons overtime is always available.  Once your route becomes second nature you become immune to the demands you do your best and that’s all you can  do.

Fedex start wage is fantastic but, this is how the company suckers people in.
Fedex benefits are great as well but, beware that this is another tactic to sucker people in.

FedEx is a company that is a leader in the transportation Industry. FedEx offers great career advancement opportunity. Very good training and preparation for other job opportunites. Management is fair, but there tends to be a lot of gossip floating around in the inside sales offices. Travel benefits and shipping discounts are awesome. You really can't compete with FedEx when it comes to these kinds of perks.
People Service Profit philosophy, prestigious name and well recognized company to work for. The benefits are great and the service provided to customers is second to none.
cons: Very hot, sometimes dirty. Minimal pay and short hours equal small checks. Everyone begins at the bottom and goes up from there. Much better environment and culture than UPS.

Hr department is useless. I was given less than 24 hr notice for orientation and after 12 weeks of waiting for an orientation I gave up. There is only one individual that runs the orientation process and she is unable to comprehend that I just needed a day or two notice to rearrange my schedule to make it to orientation. She would always say she will call me right back and never did. She also could never even tell me when the next orientation might possibly be. It would be weeks between the orientations. Overall they made me reapply for the same position over and over and could not schedule me for orientation. They also expected people to be able to make a 10am orientation on a Day during the week when I was offered a job for a 4am-8am shift.

In one prtectler and one department call Input weekend shift, the teamleader she didn't treat some of the new employee fair and equal. And she treat one person better then other person better than other one in there. (Favoritiasom)

Takes 15+ years to top out. Unless you are willing to move around, no real opportunity for advancement. Even then you have to jump through hoops. It's a corp., so a lot of red tape and b.s. You are a number in the grand scheme of things. Macro-managed at times. Unrealistic goals. Profit outweighs people, and service.

Career growth is very slow. Management try to treat people, whether you are working hard or not working, the same, that demotivates people who works really hard. Management need to consider this much better

If you are in leadership, you are expected to work a lot of hours over 10 and literally walk through fire to be able to get promoted. They talk about safety as a priority but put their employees at risk expecting them to show up for work with 2 feet of snow outside. Also talk about work life balance but expect you to work 12 hour days.  Healthy benefits are the worst they ever been in 15 years.
Hitting the delivery times are difficult to sustain per the system driven requirements … real life road conditions and out dated mapping is an obstacle in itself.

The downsides to working at Fedex is simple, they are great manipulators. They tell people what they want to hear but, do the complete opposite. All Fedex cares about is their reputation, and BRAND. They treat their frontline employee's aweful but, keep in mind that these are the people that make FEDEX very rich. Overall the company has made alot of money throughout the years,  now they over work their employee's, and company expections/goals are just unreasonable to achieve.
Politics and the gossip that goes around, and since the corporation is a large one the pay is not very good initially. It is a sacrifice initially for a long term career success.

As with any large company, can become a little political when looking for promotion opportunities. Although there are many great promote-from-within programs the company offers such as Aspire to Management, HR needs to do a better job of ensuring that fresh talent has a fair shot at being selected for vacancies.

review: One of the greatest companies and work cultures founded on a people service profit philosophy
Fedex Courier driver, hard work but feels good.
pros:
One gets to work for one of the 3 major transportation majors in the world
Get to establish a good work-life balance
One of the largest IT spenders in the world
You get paid by the day, the faster you finished the sooner you go home. If you take care of your customers and drive safely then its like your the boss and everyone is happy.
Absolutely love my managers, (Lambardo & Erica). Very family oriented and accommodating company. Lots of little incentives and little competitions.

Even at Part Time- you have the ability to work additional hours through the Ahead system and often come close to or past a 40 hour week. Especially during Peak. If your willing to work they are willing to pay. If you work a day that's not on your schedule it's time 1/2.
Fast paced amd my co-workers and bosses are easy to get along with.

Great Benefits - one of the best insurance packages around, lots of incentives for taking care of your heath and discounted gym memberships
Stable Company
Growth Opportunities

FedEx cares about their people and they make every effort to come through even in tough times.  FedEx is a large company with lots of opportunities and awesome brand recognition.  Amazing focus on work life balance!

FedEx was a great company to work for, plenty of resources available to compensate their employees.  A lot is expected of you physically to work in this position, and it all needs to be done quickly, but you are rewarded for your hard work.
Good pay and a fairly good bonus package.

Company has provided extensive training and tools to help me become a better professional.  Great benefits and fantastic tuition reimbursement program.  Employer is great to provide flexible hours while getting your education.
cons:
Projects generally takes a long time to implement (think multiple years!)
Not a nimble and agile company in terms of getting things done...if your looking to achieve a lot, this is not a place for you
So conservative in approach (from a legal standpoint), it actually hurts business
Not too many, its not a job for someone out of shape, apartments and some businesses can be a pain in the butt to find. If your a cover driver you will do many routes.
The weather outside is the weather you work in. If it's hot, it's hot in warehouse. If it's cold, it's cold in warehouse. Not enough full time positions. Very physically demanding.
Very difficult to find an open full time position. When the jobs do come available, there's usually several people with more time in than you bidding.
The heat is terrible , it would be alittle more bearile if there was a fan in my work area.

would be great to have more opportunities to shadow and learn about other departments for tea members who maybe unsure about their next career steps
slow to resolve IT issues, even though we have an internal IT team it often takes a long time to resolve simple IT issues
Salaries are slightly lower than market but the job security and people service profit lifestyle really makes up for that!  Satellite locations may have lesser opportunities.

Working at the ramp in Austin, TX, the summer months are tough, the warehouse is hot, working on an aircraft is hot, but your body gets used to it. Like with any work place, there is miscommunication that leads to extra work needing to be done which is often frustrating.

Horrible Management and dishonest Human Resources Department. They shared confidential and privileged information on a EEOC complaint that was filed against those who the complaint was about   Those accused Managers retaliated and nothing could stop them. Filing more complaints resulted in complete dishonesty and falsification on FedEx's HR Department.  This needs to be investigated by the Justice Department . Documented facts have now been given to attorneys in two other lawsuits against FedEx.  I will continue to pursue this as I am currently a FedEx stock holder and will take this public. In Utah it is legal to have a secret recording device. I have more than several recordings of FedEx Management making illegal comments.   I would suggest anyone having Management issues with FedEx middle Management take a recording device into any and all meeting with those Managers. Protect  yourself  and if you have issues file with the Justice Department.

The pay is not the greatest.  Pay increases are minimal.  With a Bachelors degree and over 10+ years of experience, I'm getting ready to leave due to $39K a year.  Not meeting my financial needs, but I will certainly miss the company.

review: Great job if you just do it
Frontline Employees are not happy at FedEx
Another "used to be a good place to work" company...
The compensation and benefits package are very good, benefits better than most
pros: Absolutely love the job and the company. It is physically demanding at times and just mentally demanding enough to keep things from getting boring. Basically show up on time, do your job, and get paid without any of the typical BS associated with other jobs. Fantastic especially if you have another job during the day.
Health benefits are reasonable and inexpensive.
It's a steady job.All I can think of

Great Benefits, Company provides good training to mean job requirements, FedEx has a reputation for having a no-nonsense work environment where performance is constantly tracked, measured, and available to employee during annual review. All calls are recorded and may be monitored and graded by managers of other call centers reducing discrimination or favoritism.
Decent pay and benefits plenty of flex on your schedule, ok upward mobility.

Insurance but as of 2015 because of Obamacare that benefit is gone...
Company has a small pension...
Good pay, friendships were easily made, team leaders were always friendly and caring of there workers. Good benefits and room for advancement .

Strong company with a world-wide known name and reputation; all in all - a great place to start one's career or reinforce one's CV with. Very strong operations, planning and IT units with a variety of internal development programs and training courses, shall it be required, highly professional teams.

The compensation and benefits package are very good, benefits better than most.  The company has good core motives and does a lot for charity.   There's a tuition assistance program that can pay for almost everything except parking and books.  The mail order prescription plan can save you tons of money.  There are airline discounts for regular part time and fulltime employees as well as many other discounts available.   You can get a workout on the job while getting paid--because much of the entry level work is physical.  We call it being an industrial athelete!

Best location in Memphis, TN to work as an IT professional.  Atmosphere is very casual.  Basically, employees can do what they want, but that isn't always a good thing.  Employees never feel too greatly pressured.  Most management is very hands off.  Company offers a very good balance between work and life.  If you have a sick child, take off.  No questions.  If you have a family emergency, take off.  No questions asked.
cons: Only con I have is some employees like to whine. Ignore them and just do your job.

FedEx managers sit in their air conditioned offices while the slaves work in 90+ degree heat in the warehouse; the use of 'Team Leaders' as their gestapo is demeaning. They are not management but think and act like they are especially with their radios on loudly they are intimidating.  The senior employees strut around like rockstars and don't work.  You can tell the slackers from the workers  by their weight. Most millennials love the job because of the short hours and 'getting paid to work out'' attitude...did I mention that safety is a joke; it's very easy to get hurt by fast moving freight coming down the chutes or by hotdogging forklift drivers... Sunday hours suck (8pm to 230AM) and you work your tail off from clockin to clockout.  You get one FedEx T shirt as a uniform.  Sort management easily gets overwhelmed if there are delays in the operation....which happens alot in the freight world.  Inexperience abounds. If you live in your parents' basement, this is the job for you !!

The numbers,you are inundated with numbers,go faster,work harder but the pay never catches up to the work. Different parts of the state make different amounts according to cost of living but the cost of living has drastically gone up but Fedex still hasn't done anything about it. You have satisfied employees but they are not front-line employees,no matter what you do at Fedex the public recognizes the Drivers for Fedex no one else.15 years it takes to get to maximum pay at Fedex,UPS 36 months. When the Unions come into Fedex which they will,Fedex will have no one to blame but itself.

Little chance for meaningful promotion, Some performance (matrix) measurements are contrary to customer service. A focus on call time (for example) pressures employee to get off call regardless if customer issue has been resolved.

They brag on how they never laid anyone off all the time, and its true they just offer you an impossible job in another state.  Office politics are idiotic the higher you go.  If you have a good upper manager then you are golden but if they don't like you they will give you jobs that force you to quit or go to another shift.

PAY!  I have been with them for over 8 years and only those who have been around 17 or more years have competetive pay.  In 8 years I've gotten one raise for over 2% and as a company we had gone for 1.5 years with no raise at all...keep in mind this company does quite well.  Raises are not based on merit.  The formula changes every year with the majority getting 2% if at all.  New hires make very close to what an 8 year veteran does.  Dangerous Goods reps get no extra monies for the responsibility and are held accountable.  The management training program, for couriers who want to be a manager,  is a joke and it is done entirely on the candidates personal time...Fed Ex will not pay for any training or travel expenses. They are expert at taking an excellent employee and destroying that employees attitude!

fast paced heavy lifting  for long periods of time. Managers could have been more helpful and thoughtful of their workers. Weird hours and times that we would start and finish work. Never had enough help on the shift so the workers working that particular shift had to work harder and do more than one activity.

As often in large companies, decisions may take a while to be made, usually much bureaucracy involved into anything that has to do with back office operations. Career opportunities are not as high as expected - much tasks are now being shifted to India & Poland, outsourced.

The current high oil prices have me considering other employ, because of the negative affect it has had on other airlines recently.  FedEx is heavily aircraft driven, which gives the cause for my concern.  Upper management can be out of touch with lower level employees.  The shiftwork can be demanding on family and social lives because FedEx is a 24 hour company.  There are opportunities for advancement, but it may mean taking part-time work for a while in order to get a better full-time job.

Compensation is good for the area but not on par with other world class companies.
Benefits are sub-par for a company with 500K+ employees.
Senior/Executive Management is pathetic.
Lots of employees take advantage of the relaxed atmosphere and don't get their work done and it falls to other people.  The folks doing the extra work don't get compensated accordingly and the folks not doing the work don't get "punished".

review: Overall I enjoy going to work everyday.
Great place to work...if you want to settle down for good
FedEx has blessed me with a rewarding career and opportunities I wouldn't have received elsewhere!
Loved the job, had issues with management styles
Fedex Express is a great place to work
Great place for those looking for a good work/life balance and a reasonable benefits/compensation package.
Great company that takes care of their employees.
pros: Great Pay, Great Benefits, and good people. Fedex Ground is one the best companies to work for in the world. Great chance for advancement if you work hard for it.

The benefits and work-life balance is terrific.  The work environment is great.  Attrition is very low and hence job security is high.  If you are planning to start a family and want a secure job with good benefits and work-life balance, this is a great place to work.  Even though the salaries are not flamboyant, considering the job location is in Memphis, down South one can save a lot of money as the cost of living is quite low compared to the West or East coast.

FedEx is a diverse company with a lot of opportunities.  My experience is at Express as a driver and manager for many years.  Couriers can make a decent living wage.  The job is physically demanding but rewarding for those who refuse to sit at a desk.  Couriers are not required to have college experience, but can make comparable wages.  The culture is good, though seems to be less customer centered as time goes on.  If you like to move around FedEx has the ability for couriers to transfer to any other available positions in other stations/cities.  Great if you want to see lots of places.  

As far as management, it was a good job as well.  Comp is fair, but not highly performance based.   It's the type of job that uses the same skills every day, but no two days are alike.  Managers have some flexibility as far as their schedules.  Once your team has launched and all is well, you can go on road and spend time one-on-one with employees, which is fun.  Peak is a pain and 2 straight months of 55 hours weeks, depending on where you live though, they great summers can efficiency of the FedEx machine make up for it.

This company provides excellent benefits and retirement options as soon at your start state which is unheard of in this industry. They also have 401k and a pension, also unheard of in today's business world. The work expectations are reasonable and job support is there if you need it.

Professional atmosphere.  Depending on the management, you are not micro-managed; however you do have to communicate well and often the status of your projects as you would expect. If you have a capable manager you will thrive. Somewhat flexible on start and end times and lunch break if your circumstances need some flexibility. Some allow you to come in a little earlier than others and leave a little early or come in a little later and leave a little later as long as it overlaps what most consider a normal day. Pay and benefits are good though maybe not excellent. Still have an opportunity to move up or around in the company (though not as easy as it was at one time). If you get on a good team (good managers and co-workers) it is still a good place to work and I would recommend it.

Beyond a team environment, the culture at FedEx is like my extended family. Strong leadership and a management philosophy that puts employees first. Excellent healthcare benefits and college tuition reimbursement opportunities! And more importantly FedEx supports and provides employees opportunities to give back and support local communities!
Great part time job, enjoyed the different projects you get to learn and do. Good pay. Good benefits.
Great benefits, good pay, and self satisfaction. I work with great people and they always find a way to help me out if I need it.
Someone looking for a company that strongly embraces a good work / life balance and is looking to be compensated reasonably.

Very strong culture of putting employees first so they take good care of the customers after which profits follow so they can afford to pay for high quality employees.  IT uses the latest technologies and has strong vendor relationships for good support.  Senior management is very supportive of IT because they understand the company runs on IT.
cons: Limited growth at some locations. Can be stressful during the peak season of Christmas. Long hours during the Xmas season. Filling in and being on call once you get higher up.

From a technical standpoint, if you are a software engineer and have aspirations in designing new technology and producing mind boggling innovations, forget it.  This place is terrible in software innovation.  To get something done, like getting a new laptop or even hardware infrastructure, it takes a loooong time....well, its down South :)  Like any job in the world, yes this job can also get monotonous.  But the opportunities to make it exciting and interesting....very little.  Lots of bureaucracy (which comes into picture with bigger workforce), lots of red tape and loads of meetings for planning other meetings....Yep, this place is just like Dilbert cartoons.  Sometimes I think Scott Adams worked in this place.  And if you are single or a young couple, trying to get a lot out of the city where you live, forget it.  Memphis has very little to offer except the Blues.

Pay for performance is very poorly done at FedEx.  New employees likely start at the same wages their peers are making after having been there for several years.  Its not equitable and creates a lot of resentment in the workforce that's hard to overcome.  Due to route structures, bidding, seniority, there is a lot of entitlement among the employees as well.  Essentially they reward the most experienced, best drivers with the easiest routes and schedules pushing the harder work on the newbies (and even after 5-10 years, you might still be a newbie with the amount of tenure in the workforce).

As a manager, your roles are so specialized because FedEx is so huge, that you are constantly pigeon holed into positions that don't offer continued growth.  You have to be aware of that and work your way through it if you want to move up.  Too, there is a terrible misalignment of goals to hit unrealistic numbers.  What happens in the Company makes their plan, the EVPs divided it up (leaving a little in their back pockets)... then the RVPs hang on to a little extra... then the division guys do it, too so eventually the stations end up with FTE goals that are impossible to hit.  You burn out your people and everything is negative because your station cant reach the target, meanwhile the roll up numbers are just fine and your employees could have been celebrating their good work.  Just a lot of misaligned incentives at "good ol boy" FedEx.
There are not many options for upward mobility which is common in company's this size.

True to most jobs, your manager and management team determines your success, or lack thereof, so pray for a good one! it is not as easy to move around in the company as it once was. Reorgs happen from time to time and can be ok or not depending on who you end up working for.   Need to be good at office politics.  Benefits are not as good as they once were but not sure how they compare with other companies. Out of pocket expenses can be high initially and for medical procedures. Pay is usually not as high because benefits were ONCE good enough to balance it out. Now that FedEx is so big and has been around so long the people philosophy it was founded on is not shown like it once was but it is still a good working environment for the most part. Incompetent managers look for scape goats but that's not something that just happens here....it can happen anywhere.
I don't have any complaints; after 23 years I still look forward to getting up and going to work every morning!

Not crazy about the training process. When you hire 6+ people all at once and have different trainers, you don't actually know what they have actually been told. So you may not know something and they don't know where you are at in training until it's too late. Some of the trainers are also very angry and only know swearing and yelling.
This job can be stressful when it comes to getting your packages out on time. A lot of stuff to learn in a short period of time.
Compensation mechanisms are limited simply due to the sheer size of the company. Lots of red tape tends to get in the way of getting real work done and limits true innovation.
Most opportunities in IT are in Memphis, TN - especially if you want to advance in management.  Dallas, Orlando, and Colorado Springs offer good opportunities for first line managers.

review: Despite the challenges, I enjoyed working there.
Any CEO that takes a 20% voluntary pay cut for his employees and the company is doing the right thing.
The company is very involved, warm and personable with it's employees as well as it's clients.
pros: The training is very intense, you come into your job knowing FedEx in and out.  Flexible work schedule. Good starting salary. They put a lot of time and effort into understanding that you are an employee and not a number.  Acting as a consultant instead of a sales professional.

Will make you physically fit.
Feels like a real job; you are needed and your role is serious.
Straight forward. Get to work, do your job and leave at the end of your shift and you're paid extra if work is extra; no BS.
A world wide respected organization, great benefits, fair treatment by management,  great team atmosphere, loved working there.

Very Flexible in just about everything they offer, including benefits, time off and other perks.  Employee Discount shipping.  

Everyone at FedEx from the top to the bottom is committed to pursuing the purple promise, "I will make every FedEx Experience outstanding".  Its that shared pursuit that makes this a great place to work.  Everyone carries their own weight and everyone is willing to lend a helping hand.

Great benefits, medical, and company culture.  401K match, and where else can you get a Portable Pension Account?  Most places after you leave your pension is gone.  The people and management are outstanding from the front lines up to upper management.

The culture of "Living PSP", which stands for People, Service, Profit, has been revived in this company over the last year. There is a great sense of ownership amongst the employees, and FedEx is Constantly finding ways to keep it self on the "Best Places to Work in America" list. The opportunity for lateral job moves within the company is almost endless, as every Development is highly encouraged. work function is represented, and professional
The company is loyal and an asset to it's employees especially with the economy climbing out of debt.  As long as you  give them your best you have a job.
I suppose there must be some. Most employees seem to be driven by the difficulty of finding another job in Memphis and a desire to stay there.

-awesome benefits, even for pt employees
-competitive pay when compared with industry rivals
-good balance between work and private life
Great benefits and a great company that supports its part time employees. The part time employees in the Hub are the heart of the company and Fed Ex does everything they can to keep them employed.
cons: Very limited opportunities for advancement without moving. Collaboration with different internal contacts can be difficult.

3am shift made concentration in class almost impossible no matter how early I tried to sleep beforehand.
work is actually very hard and tiring and will make you tired the rest of the day.

Customer Service department can be ineffective at resolving issues and then the sales team ends up being the customer service team and therefore not selling. Payroll increases are kept in check and no one really gets ahead financially; however, benefits are great. Promotions are hard to obtain even if you are a high performer.
Since its such a large company, it takes a lot of time and energy to amke changes.
There's been a few times that negative news has not trickled down as fast as I would have liked it to.
FedEx needs to improve its salary and bonus offering in order to retain talent and remain competitive.
Patience is a must, must and a willing spirit to be successful on the job because you literally represent the company and it's reputation. If you look bad they look bad.

Everyone I encountered at FedEx was kind and helpful and, with a very few exceptions, utterly inept. The FedEx version of innovation is to learn a new set of buzzwords, talk as though you were proceeding, and do absolutely nothing.

-upper management seems to think they are very smart, in the case of the region where I worked, they were not.

-making changes that were detrimental to our operations and the equipment we needed.

The greatest con to being a part time employee are the hours. The easiest job to get at Fed Ex is a material handler during the night shift. This job makes it very difficult to get college done which makes it difficult to further your career.

review: good place to work for with very limited upward mobility
What a great company to work for!
Co. needs to step up with pay increases
It is a good company to work for
Very good got fired 2 times but pretty sure if i were to apply again they would hire me in a heart beat.
pros: Excellent group of people. Great teamwork . Opportunities to move up the ladder. Medical and dental premiums are very low. Very generous with floater days and vacation time.
fedex has pretty good job security due to the fact it is in the transportation industry and therefore will always be needed to keep the economy gooing, also the pay is good for what I do

great company with a good business model
great benefits in terms of discounted shipping and airline discounts
culture is friendly
Friendly environment, opportunities to move up, and many benefits (Ex: discount on cell service, shipping with FedEx, schooling, etc.).

The pros are that you can move up in the company if you really work hard.  Also the incentives of being able to get discount shipping, being able to fly on interline rates are wonderful.  FedEx offers a great benefits plan and its the ideal company for a young person just starting out!
Great work environment with lots of freedom to make your own schedule. Managers were available when needed and I was able to shadow BSF employees.

Tuition reimbursment
Opportunity to change jobs and / or careers within the company
HQ in a city with low cost of living
FedEx paid a good and competitive salary, the benefit are one of the best I have encountered. It is definitely a place I will recommend others to work at.

Flexibility, ability to move do various parts of the company and country.  Great people to work around and there is an ability to go places professionally that one normally wouldn't have an opportunity to otherwise.
Great pay. If you in college this might be a great part time. Might be a lil too much for females. People is great.
cons: Very low pay. Isolated location. Not many celebrations. Most of the companies I worked for,  the boss would bring donuts or pastries. Treat us to lunch once in awhile. FedEx Trade very rarely does this.
working in a call center there tends to be a lot of micro managing going on, also I work in a high volume call center where I take in over 100+ calls per day

opportunity for growth is very limited. You will get promoted based on who and not what you know.
performance evaluation is a joke. No real reward for being a star performer.

Training could be longer, but you will learn a lot in a short amount of time. Don't be afraid to ask questions once out of training. Time-off is based on a first-come first-serve request. Must travel to work even in harsh weather conditions (heavy snow storms), and work on major holidays.

Company is outsourcing to vendors who do not understand English that well therefore it makes the job harder for their co workers...Ground contracts out to outside vendors who dont hold up to the standards of what FedEx used to be

I really had no cons with the job. However, I would make sure you understand that this job requires meeting new people and knocking on doors. You have to be aggressive and not afraid of bringing in new business.

Salary increases very limited for those that prefer to remain in non-managment positions.
No apparent effort by management to retain effective employees (counter offers, vacation days, etc.)
Very bureaucratic - too much red tape in processes
Our schedule depend on the weather; because the jet cannot land or take off during bad weather in the winter, we'll have to wait for hours sometimes. This shift our starting and ending time

FedEx is an excellent company that REALLY does care about their employees. If you apply yourself there are plenty of career opportunities available and plenty of professional development opportunities as well. Work/life balance is encouraged and supported by all levels of management. The people I work with are professional, caring and always work to get the job done right.

There is a wide range of responsibilities that allow for professional growth within the company.  Management genuinely cares about the success of their employees, and gives you the tools to complete the job.

Unfortunately, FedEx has changed a great deal over the course of the last several years. Unfortunately, the cons outweigh the pros.  If you are thinking that it is a blessing to have a job in this tight economy maybe you will look at the pros.  A sales career is not an ideal position for any college graduate looking to advance with this corporation. Let's look at the pros of a sales career at FedEx.

1) Flexiability - but this is true of sales professions at many corporations across America.

2) Stability- If you work for FedEx in a sales role (like UPS), it is highly unlikely that you will be laid-off.  Sales people are revenue driving force in the organization. FedEx and UPS (I have worked for both) recognize this; therefore, it is unlikely you will lose your job due to the economy.

3) Overall, FedEx has a good insurance package. The dental is not competitive. You can purchase a better dental insurance package from an outside company that offers a better plan and the same cost or a little less.

4) FedEx is one of the few companies offers their employees a pension. The organization is reinstating the 401K match. It was suspended during the recession.

5) FedEx does not like to lay-off employees. Unfortunately, the economy has caused some lay-offs. However, FedEx does so when the organization has no other option.  Compared to many companies, layoffs have been very low during the recession.  In this respect, FedEx does care about their employees.

I have worked at Fedex Trade Networks for 2 years, my customer performance reviews were excellent from the customers themselves which they have written to me that I have done a great job. However, internally, supervisors were not helpful, always blamed their own employees, a complete lack of teamwork, with low pay, and no growth for advancement. Everyone is to themselves. It is to my understanding that all managers should help their employees in creating success and a vision for the company. But ALL is absent, very tragic and shameful for the role as "Management", They claim "Fedex Cares" but to what extent? Is it only for a show to the public?? Out of the years that I have worked with Fedex, the work atmosphere is hostile, intimidating and gloomy for all the employees. Compared with the shooter from what has occurred in Orlando, I don't know who is worse.

The company keeps takings benefits and pay away and we have no recourse and now they have frozen out traditional pension plan in favor of a portable plan that pays much less
It is a large company and does have a lot of complexity.

The cons of working with FedEx are that there is CONSTANT change, and mediocre salaries.  It can be a challenging company to work for due to the high demand, but also rewarding to those that work hard.

Working as a field Account Executive at FedEx is a low-paying thank less job.   The salary would be fair if you were working a 40-45 hour a week job.  If you are going to be an effective sales person by hitting your numbers and closing new business, you will work long hours.  This might not be a problem if you are compensated for your efforts. 

Also, the job does not really require that an individual work as long if management allowed their employees to manage their time effectively to get the tasks completed to get new packages “on the belt.”  There is a lot of administrative work. The FedEx internal systems are low and outdated. If the sales employees were hourly, I am certain that the organization would work on streamlining many of their internal processes to save their employees time and to make the job easier. 

FedEx does not believe that their sales people are intelligent individuals who can make business decisions.  This can be seen by how they manage their people.  Your focus is not just sales.  You are the customer service person for every account in your territory even for account that you do not receive commission for… FedEx has the practice of giving the Sales Executive cell phone to everyone… Any person who finds your card will be calling you.  It was ridiculous.  The list of problems with this position goes on and on. 

If you want to have a life outside of FedEx, do not apply here. If you want to spend time with your family, do not apply here. If you want to spend your evenings watching television while working on FedEx pricing contracts or responding to e-mails almost every night of the week, then this is the JOB for you. 

I do not mind hard work. I was an effective sales person… BUT PAY ME FOR MY EDUCATION, PROFESSIONALISM, TIME AND EFFORT! This is truly the JOB from HELL!  For those you read this post, I was not a poor performer. I always had good reviews and brought on large accounts.  I attempted to give this company my best during the time I was employed there and make the best of a BAD situation until a new door opened.  It is not worst it!  

In addition, to all of these problems, the promotion process is nearly impossible within sales department.  As an account executive, you can only be promoted to a sales executive (which is the same position with a new title). Your pay increases significantly, but the requirements change almost yearly and the company makes it almost impossible to get promoted. There are a very limited number of corporate and worldwide account manager positions. People who have those positions rarely resign or quit. When one becomes available everyone is trying… promotion regardless of work ethic is nearly impossible.  UPS promotes their people fairly; FedEx does not. I have worked for both… At UPS, I was respected and treated like the educated individual that I am. At FedEx, I was a robot without a brain.
