A leading corporation in its field. Very good corporate culture which provides employees with competitive pay, benefits and work-life balance. Employee recognition for a job well done. Opportunity for training and advancement. Stable work environment.
it worked with my schedule while I went to school. Saw some extra hours when I could make it. Good environment, good management and coworkers were fun.
Some of the benefits are pretty good. Our location's team members are also very dedicated. I enjoy working with them a lot. My management team is average.

1. Great work environment
2. Very good people policies
3. Low cost living
4. Great senior management
reputable company, service sells itself. very open communication from superiors to employees. really put "people first". excellent opportunities for advancement.
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy with anything that needs done.  Any project that would take a week to complete will take 10 weeks due to all the paperwork associated with it.  Medical insurance is expensive and bad.

Sometimes moving into different roles in the company is based on who you know, networking is necessary to advance. Therefore, having a strong skill set may not get you into a position you may actually be qualified for.
I really cannot think of any thing negative.  Will always live by the PURPLE PROMISE.
The hours are minimal even if the hourly compensation is relatively high per hour.  repetitive work can become mind-numbing.

This Company is run by robots, managers work is primarily to cover Fed EX liability right or wrong. Any and all mistakes, injury,accidents, customer complaint is dumped in subordinates laps. A lot of favoritism given to minorities. Pay for the work performed ( courier) is sub standard and pay raises move at a snails pace.Safety in the work place is said to be paramount however you are expected to work at break neck speeds in order to save every minute of time on the clock and service needs. constantly understaffed.

A number of seasoned employees/managers have either retired or accepted the recent voluntary employee buyout offer. Shift to outsourcing in a number of areas with resources who don't possess the level of knowledge of the people they replaced.

I moved about a thousand packages in an hour or so.  It was a physical job, which I prefer, but it happen to be pretty rough on my wrists. Took quite a few months for the aching pain to go away, but I enjoyed the job.

Work-life balance is definitely the biggest con. Not many initiatives have been taken to better balance the two. I'd like to see more attention paid to ensuring workers have the time they need to balance their personal lives. The job is important but there still needs to be better work life balance provided. For that reason, I think I should be able to leave only a half star in the work-blance rating category

1. Low chances of growth
2. Exceptional performance not rewarded with exceptional career growth - little difference in mediocre and high performers growth/salary structure.
3. Memphis is not the most vibrant city (but has low cost of living)

make sure  you have a good manager, makes all the difference... they expect us to  be "consultants" and they provide us with the tools and support to do so for our customers which is what makes us stand out from our competitors... all that's missing is the pay.

review: Good, but not exactly what I expected
Stay away from the Express Division
Good workout, average pay, great benefits
Perfect for extra income while still working a full-time position at another company
Senior Express Clearance Operations Import Coordinator
pros: Most of the people are easy to get along with and the work environment is friendly. The hours can be flexible but that's because you will likely need to put in 40+ hours every week, just not at a set 9-5 type of schedule.

Very committed employees; many of the people I work with have been with FedEx for decades. For me, it has been a great opportunity for building experience and exposure to new technologies. Fairly flexible hours where I can take off for parts of the day if needed for various needs (dr. appointment, family activity,...).
Easy job, they don't ask much from you in Express and Services divisions. Ground is very demanding

Great work life balance, Huge Company, Career Advancement Opportunities in places all over the US and Internationally, Great Benefits, Caring Executive Management (took pay cuts and offered buy outs instead of handing out lay offs), Very Understanding Management.
Fast paced environment, room to move up internally, good workout.  Good benefits, 401k. And a pension plan

Remote
2weeks vacation 
Pension
401k
Personal,sick and flh

Very Ethical company 
Provides Best in Class service to our Customers
Opportunity with other outstanding individuals

Great Pay
Excellent Benefits
Ideal hours for someone looking to work a full-time position at another company and have this as their part-time income

Pretty much impossible to get fired unless you are late or call in often. 
Above average paid time off.
Challenging work, days off because I worked at night.  Good Management team at my location. Opportunities to advance were present.
cons: Work life balance doesn't exist much in the IT area. There are cycles but, more often than not, 40+ hours/week including nights and weekends is quite the norm. Salaries could be much better as well.

The work/life balance can be focused more on work and less life. The culture of the company, or at least the area I work in, is to put as many hours in a week towards work as possible and maintaining a life outside of work is not encouraged at all.

In Express, there is no incentive to perform well. The company wants to shrink to keep costs down- to a point where service levels are at all time lows. There is no room for advancement as well as no job security in Express. Services is a great place for staff and Ground is where you want to be for advancement and reward.
Company as a whole leans more toward the older generation that founded it. Needs younger blood.
Depending on where u work it is a lot of lifting.  Lazy people need not apply.  Hard workers are not rewarded like they used to be

Taking sick time affects your performance review. They allow you to do shift bids but you'll never get the shift you want because everything goes by seniority. Can't take pto during Christmas holidays. No flexible hours. If you are hired on a certain shift, thats really it for a few years until they start taking of 15-30 mins at a time. Pay is low. No room for advancement, even though I was told differently during my interview process. You have ppl working for 10+ years just stuck in the same position.  Unless you relocate to Memphis. Managers also do not work with you to get you to the next level.

Transportation industry currently has an excess in capacity making the environment very competitve
There is a large block of tenured (25+ yrs) that would have retired save for the great recession.  This group holds a large number of executive management postion.  This makes promotional opportunities very competitive.  This will likely change in the next 3-5 years

Physically demanding, although I don't mind, it can become strenuous at times.
Weather can be a factor as it is inside and outside from an airport hangar.
Part-time hours, although if you are looking for that, then it is a great source of income.

No room for advancement and if there is the work load is not worth advancing. 
No rewards for employees, everyone feels undervalued and over worked. They do not care about quality- only quantity- which is why Customs is constantly threatening to return to paper submission for FDA shipments and a lot of extra paperwork is now needed for USGR. In fact if Customs looked into shipments more they would see that customers are constantly providing tariffs with lower duty to save money. Accuracy is not a factor at all here. 
In 3 years I've gotten a total of 16 cents in raises- that's $332.80 more than what I was hired at- after 3 years of above average work. There is no motivation to be an exceptional employee.
Most managers are lazy or mean and deserve to be fired. 
Health insurance is terrible.

Warehouse work, dusty environment however that comes with the territory.  Management can make all the difference, if you have a good team, you are good to go, a bad team, well you can fill in the blanks.

review: Great job but not a career
Safe and secure in a job I adore
date_position: Oct 30, 2016 - Fed Ex Ground Package Handler
Sep 14, 2015 - Fed Ex Ground Package Handler
pros: Always have work available when I want.  Overtime is time and a half over 8 hours per day or 40 hours per week.  Social interaction with most of the public in their workplace.
Great community, good pay, with a good opportunity to be promoted inside the company. Everyday cardio workout for those who need it
Short work days, food on occasion, good benefits, and nice pay
They have excellent top notch benefits for full time employees.

Great pay for a college student. Full benefits even for part time employes.  School incentive programs.  Availability to move up in the company.  Availability to move around the US within the company. Paid vacation.

FedEx is true to the work-life balance methodology.  They support all decisions based on family because they realize family comes first.  As long as your work is getting done in a reasonable time frame, no request is unreasonable.
Excellent company to work for lots of opportunity for advancement. Company on very solid ground no lay off worries.

* Work life balance
* Competitive Salary in Memphis based on cost of living (not so much elsewhere)
* Good perks especially the 5% of salary pension match
Great Benefits even for part time, tuition reimbursment, not at a desk all day, people were good and regular customers became like family

It gets you in shape,  in less than 6 months you will lose a great deal of weight if you put enough effort into it.     

pay is higher than most companies offer

They value your safety to the up most extreme

If you are part-time then you may request to work an extra shift to earn more money
cons: Extreme pressure when delivering.  This job will age you prematurely and will make you weary when you find it hard to meet the increasingly greater expectations placed upon you.
Working out everyday, this job can take a toll on you mentally and physically. More physically than mentally. And it's very dusty in the trailers from time to time
People call off or show up late often, no drug testing, no repercussions for lazy workers, unappreciative drivers

Very pro man. Instead of showing corporate how things really work when they visit they put on a dog and pony show so that corporate is not aware of changes that need to be done to benefit the company.
Lots of promotions are based on seniority  rather than who is the best candidate.  Can be very unorganized at times.  Met my ex-girlfriend there.
As with all salaried positions, sometimes it is required to work longer hours every now and then, taking home your laptop to work from home at night or on the weekends.

Very unhappy with pay progression. I have been an ops manager for 8 years and I am only 9% above what a new manager would start out and our bonuses that they hang over you like a carrot have been terrible. Also our medical benefits every year have gotten worse and more expensive.

* Wide Career bands (i.e. your pay can increase significantly from one end of a job band to the other end, but the title may not change)
* Limited career growth
* Salary outside of Memphis is not competitive

weather could be harsh ,esp in south, dog bites hurt, stepping in and out of truck all day wears on your knees. Christmas, Mothers Day and other high quanity shipping days your not going to see your family much.

Physically tolling

If you live on your cell-phone,   expect to leave it in your car for your shift,  NO recording devices allowed ( as per notifications on the security check-in station ) ,   so if you need to keep in touch with the outside world,  you'll have to ask management for permission to dial out ( work/life balance a 2 star rating )

review: I LOVED working at FedEx as a Customer Service Research Asst.
FedEx has a culture that focuses on people,  service and profit. Individuals are responsible for their own development.
Worked for this company for 27 years. Awesome company and great people to work with.
FedEx, a good place for single/stay-at-home parents, students, and those with disabled children in need of good benefits
Great Place to work but needs to be more diversity in upper management
pros: Working hours are what I was looking for.  Access to benefits.  Paid holidays, 2 weeks vacation 1 week of sick pay

Awesome insurance, tuition reimbursement, family leave, military leave, vacation and sick time, professional culture, stability, and promotion from within, several awards and tokens of appreciation, a family culture, and very professional company to work for and retire from!
Enjoy working in any environment. Very fast learner at anything and complete all my tasks in a timely manner. Very easy to get alone with.
The company is respected in the industry and the world. Good benefits and culture.
Good benefits, good training depending on station and manager opportunity to learn and advance. Open door policy with your manager and promoted from within
The biggest benefit to this job is it's flexibility.  A good place for a person just starting in sales out of college.
Good salary and benefits.  You get great travel benefits also.  Fast paced. Great working hours. Company allows employee an opportunity to advance rather easily also.
Good pay. Decent benefits. Meet lots of people. Energetic job. Working closely with other couriers and making friends that last forever.

- Flexible hours
- Above average hourly pay
- Yearly raises
- Fast paced, work can double as a workout
- 3 day weekends
- Seniority is valuable for promotion
This is an awesome place to work. People are friendly, cordial and professional. Everybody works together as a team and towards common goal.
cons: They can change the time you some in on a week to week basis.  No Union.  Be ready to work in all kinds of weather conditions.
This position is meant to be a stepping stone to a higher position. Please have a plan to move upward, soon after you are hired.
Don't like to be distracted when on the job. Like for my job duties to be explained to me as correctly as possible. Don't like working in an unhealthy environment.

It's a very large company. To progress, relationships matter. Under the FedEx umbrella are various operating companies with different policies and procedures that may be confusing for new employees and customers.
Sometimes lack of management follow through can result in an environment without team work and lack of acknowledged for the hard working dependable members of the team

If you are a professional sales person, you will find the money will never be here; no matter what big accounts you bring in. The commission off the margin made is based off what the operations team can cover the loads at. Not a lot of opportunity for growth; only the chosen few seem to get it, no matter how well or hard you work.
If you are not open to change the work may not be right for you. Could be an issue if you are not an outdoor person.
Local mngt can make own rules and not follow co.policy. work some holidays. Gotta work in the rain and snow. Jumping in & out of the truck all day. Bad on the knees.

- Cannot support self or family with this income alone
- Difficult to get a full time job or salaried position
- Hard to work more than 17 hours, must come in extra day just to get 17

Diversity in upper management can be improved. Diversity includes women and minorities. I think FedEx does a great job in putting women in upper management but there is opportunity for minorities to be included in that place too especially in IT and Marketing.

review: A great transitional/in between career in preparing for something better
pros: The benefits are very good for a part time job. They also have a cafeteria where you can get some food to eat

All depends on the contractor you work for.   Mine was excellent.  Worked with me if time off was needed.  Paid vacation (contractor dependent).  Your customers are almost always happy to see you.  Good job for young, healthy individuals, not a career path.

Excellent benefits.  If you exercise a positive attitude, show up when expected, and do the work, they will return the respect and help you to advance as part time or to move to full time.  The benefits cost the employee almost nothing and are excellent.
Great benefits and very fair management and company policies regarding employee support and benefits beyond the excellent hourly rate.

great benefits
pension plan
well respected employer
job security as long as you perform
good people to work with and for at times
Great benefits even for part time employees, shifts that allow you to work another job, good pay rate for part time work

Generally independent work, driving a company delivery truck and meeting customers through out the day. There are clear standards and expectations of efficiency especially in the number of deliveries per hour, time between departing the warehouse and one's first delivery, etc.
There are some incredible people to learn from within the organization. If you want to learn how to sell and sell great, this is the company to work for.
Wonderful company, believes in People, Service, Profit... In that order.  Very active in the local community and throughout the world.  I am proud to say that I worked for FedEx.
Great people. The market leader in shipping and logistics. The CEO is fantastic.
cons: the managers yell at you a lot and can be mean. I don't think FedEx has a union so that could be the reason

No benefits outside of the contractor providing paid vacation. No health insurance, no 401(k), nothing .  The contractors cannot afford to provide these things and still make a profit.  Ever-changing expectations from corporate.  Work is rain or shine. 
 Hard work, physically demanding and eventually will break down your body.
Must be physically willing to do the work. Almost everyone starts out doing physical tasks.
Training is a bit rushed.

Politics when it comes to promotions some times
Nonexistent work/life balance in November and December
Pay could be better
contractor legal issues/lawsuits
Not enough career advancement opportunities
Lots of employees who do nothing, stand around and have to have help for their work to be completed because no one can leave shift till certain tasks are completed

A new courier is limited to only part-time hours. It takes a few years, and only when senior couriers retire or move up, for full-time slots to become available. In addition, even with a part-time schedule, sometimes it is difficult to get a second occupation because the length of a work day depends on several factors: personal delivery times, when a shipment of packages from the airport arrives, logistical issues at HQ, etc.
Difficult to get promoted into Management.

They have a high level of expectations and can create some stressful situations.  Also moving away from remote workers, while the rest of the world moves towards remote workers, FedEx is moving away from remote workers
Low salary, tough to advance.  Recent erosion of great people programs. Senior management has lost touch with the employees.

review: excellent company that cares for it's employees
Secure company, it's not going anywhere.
Great company, great culture, but a slow-moving giant!
Not paid enough for such an overwhelming amount of work
Fedex is an impressively well run company
date_position: Mar 28, 2017 - Fed Ex Ground Package Handler
pros: Collaborative environment with learning opportunities and challenging work. Every employee has a direct impact on the bottom line and are able to see how their individual contributions help the growing company take it's place as a top competitor in the market. Competitive salaries, great benefits, and employee perks make this a great place to work.

You always have an opportunity to move around the hub once you been there for 3 months.  If you work offload on the planes you will make a lot more money.  You will find yourself hitting overtime or there.
Lots of opportunity for growth, small teams that foster collaboration, intelligent people, cafeteria onsight, decent parking, great neighborhood
FedEx is a good company with good benefits, good salary, and good advancement opportunities. I highly recommend working there. Go for it.
It's secure at FedEx. Hiring all the time. Don't necessariy have to perform above average, being liked is most important.
Positive Culture. Flexible Management. Cafeteria/Gym in Building. Pension. Free Parking. Lots of Opppourtinity.

When I needed to move closer to my parents hometown due to their health issues, FedEx  moved me back where i needed to be. I am thankful to those that facilitated the move and to FedEx for the opportunities and for working with their employees.
Mindless work; you don't really have to think much or deal with customers

Great benefits all around, for most part, great management team depending which company and/or division you work at, but overall great sense of appreciation and value of employees.  Multiple opportunities to grow and they do try to hire from within.
The management is well selected; the facilities and concern for employees is a priority; and the work is variable , constant, and fast paced.
cons: with the slowing economy and not as much natural attrition, opportunities for advancement are lacking
The weather is very hot in the summer and very cold in the winter.  Be prepared.

Heavy politics, mistakes can haunt you, cutthroat competition, some managers are not available to support their team, can be difficult to be mentored, silo environment with heavy walls that are blocking against success.
FedEx is a large company, so sometimes you feel lost in the crowd. Management is military is style, top down directed, with not much opportunity for employee recommendations.
It's a male centric company. also management will convey one message but reward employees for something completely different.
Lack of Resources. Lack of Young Talent. Too Structured of a Pay/Promotion Scale. Lack of Work From Home Options / Flexibility. No Free Coffee. Tenured Employees / Political Enviroment.
Tight staffing model for smaller stations. Never enough time

Packager handlers are rewarded for unsatisfactory work; weak links are expected to be subsidized by everyone else; some employees handle far far less volume than others (I average 700-900 packages per day, others handle 80-10); Managers worry too much about efficiency without knowing how much more difficult they make the job; instead of listening to employee concerns, manager rattle off platitudes about "positive attitudes", and "slow and steady wins the race", without actually having the experience of handling such back-breaking work; they say they hire and promote from within, yet as an employee, you are still required to go through bureaucratic online application process rather than being directly promoted; TERRIBLE electronic equipment; favoritism and inability to properly discipline employees; everyone speaking Spanish
Politics instead of talent and abilities/capabilities in enabling one to move up the corporate ladder. Pay not always competitive.

There havent been any major cons in my experience so far. Like any industrial job, there is constant noise (belts running, etc), but I couldnt see it leading to even slight hearing damage unless one worked full time for years.

review: Excellent company, excellent employees, leading-edge projects for the best and the brightest
FedEx Services has many opportunities throughout the company
pros: steady job, great on the job training and great support at your finger tips on the computer as well as the teams if you need questions answered.

Good health, dental and vision insurance, nice 401k matching, great people, decent pay and opportunity to be outside meeting people. College degree not required and generally easy work for a manual labor job.

Love the people, love the job and the environment. The company as a whole fostered a great sense of comradely and purpose. While the job was sometimes difficult, it was always worth it to be part of something that large.
Good benefits, career opportunities, good pay, convenient hours to work around the clock, diverse work environment, team work is mandatory! Safe environment
Great team atmosphere. Smart people, who work on good interesting projects. Tasks are dependent upon management direction. Excellent work life balance

Pay was $13/hr and you could work over college breaks. Managers were super flexible. Co-workers liked you because you were seen as temporary employment and didn't pose a threat for promotions/bonuses. They feed you food weekly. It's a basic position but employers always wanted to talk about my time there.

As an IT analyst, I had opportunities to change career direction and specialties every 3-5 years.
Management has re-focused on PSP Philosophy - Take care of People, people provide great Service for customers, leading to Profit for shareholders.
Recent voluntary buy-out offer will provide more opportunities for remaining staff.
Pay and benefits. Good supervisors, employees, security and staff. Very good sturdy employment, and supervisors are always willing to assist you at any given time.
Good compensation, better than average benefits, historically long term job satisfaction and most people stay at least 10 years, but many stay much longer
Large company with many opportunities for advancement, learning, and growth. Small-company culture and atmosphere - everyone is extremely genuine, nice, helpful and down to earth.
cons: due to the nature of the business your days can be very long and not much chance to move up and advance your career unless you have a degree

Seniority policy makes it difficult to move into a decent full time position or get a vacation on a week you want. Part time couriers will likely work in the evening which can be a strain on family life.
When you deal in time as a commodity, the expectations can often feel more than a little daunting

Different personalities like any place , when weather is hot it's hotter on building and voiced versa. When cold several layers needed, months where can go over hours (peak season) during the holidays

Kinda slow. New technologies take time to get so people leaving the company might take time to adjust to the fast paced life outside. 
Health benefits are definitely wanting and other perks are non existent.
There's no AC so it's hot in the summer and freezing in the winter. It's hard labor.
Downsizing from voluntary buy-out may result in a dynamic environment for a while.

Very strenuous work with certain aspects. Can be a dangerous work environment if not taken with caution at times. A bit stressful. I would not recommend this job with anyone who has a health problem in regards to stress either.

There are not a lot of levels to advance through promotional opportunities.  You cannot come in with an expectation to advance at the rate some other companies have ... be patient, wait for your time, repeat if necessary.
Few cities with corporate job availability; large company so sometimes it's hard to get your ideas out there; sometimes technology could be more advanced

review: overall its been a pretty good company to work for. Very secure work place.
Senior ECO Coord. @ FedEx Trade Networks
FedEx-no longer a good company to work for.
Great Company but Career Growth hard to come by
pros: FedEx was a great company with great benefits. Flexible schedule and weekends off. Paid vacation and holidays off . Great part time job

Good working environment, decent pay and will afford you time-off  as needed. Plenty of overtime.
Great opportunity to learn and get exposure other governmental agencies.
Great pay. Friendly atmosphere. Have enjoyed for the most part, working there.

The benefits and vacation time are great. If you are favored by upper management it’s a decent job to have but the skewed office politics and “witch hunt” mentality that the site manager cultivates does not create many pro for most employees.
Fast paced. Great benefits. Motivating atmosphere. Paid vacations. Surrounded by Honest, hard working people. Managers are fair and will help you move up as long as you work hard and are responsible
Work exposes you to all types of marketing and event coordination as well as other types of business interactions with prepares you for the corporate universe
Benefits are fantastic.  That's it.

Pension eligible after 3 years, 14 working days off, unlimited sick days, great "brand", free range on inet use at the office, nobody monitors you, like to do a lot of out of office events, get interline travel benefits, corporate perks, great discounts pretty much everywhere you can think of

The company does provide stable employment (they only lay off team members in extreme financial situations).
Benefits (while slowly being reduced due to health care costs) are competitive and better than normal.
Working atmousphere is fairly casual.
Executive support and hard work. Extremely dedicated work force that keeps customer first focus.
cons: I really enjoyed working at FedEx. The people were nice and helpful. Really my only complaint was there was not enough hours
Work with US Customs and have to be flexible to the various changes as they occur. Overtime is required and limited growth within sub-company.

Too much OT for me. They need to have a more level work flow throughout the work week. Instead of having certain days with a heavy volume. Also,have an even number of people to work every inch of warehouse, functions.

There is no sense of community at this office. The site manager is sexist to put it simply and will absolutely pit her employees against one another. For some reason her management team seems unconcerned with dropping productivity at the this site and her ability to hire capable people and retain those people. This trend will continue until she is relieved from her position and a more forward thinking person is allowed to step up.
Can get stressful if you can’t handle multiple tasks at once. Until you get a routine going. Not for everyone. Must be able to keep up with time/task expectations as Their logo is “The World on Time”
Very competitive there are thousands of employees that you will have to fight against to make sure you rise to the top

Used to be a good company, then things changed, now the company no longer cares about its front line couriers in the least.  They want to squeeze blood from a stone and work couriers to death while showing favoritism to friends.  Management is an utterly useless group of fools, disorganized and incompetent.  Perhaps if the company would stop strong-arming anyone who utters the word "union" and let us organize, we would have SOME rights as employees, instead of being complete slaves to their foolish whims.

promotions are so hard to come by unless you are willing to relocate after working in inside sales for 18 months, working in inside sales for 18 months until you can look for field sales jobs sucks, and then its up to the manager to help you out which doesnt help out at all!!!

The process and bureaucracy is very overbearing, very similar to working for the government (old school style management)
All of the leadership and upper management is centered in Memphis.  You cannot expect to progress within the company without moving to Memphis.
The company has grown by acquiring other companies and has a challenge integrating those companies together (both systems and process).

Long hours at times. Very rigid work process that is at times difficult to get exceptions when needed. However, at organization this size the standardization is needed and exceptions are being considered more frequently than in the past.

review: A great Company that is doing so much right.
Thankful for the experience and knowledge I gained as well as the relationships
pros: Fun job, got paid for a great work out everyday! Employee benefits weather you are full or part time which seemed to provide generous time off even working part time.
Great pay and great benefits. Great christmas tips
The envirmonment was positive. Great coworkers. I enjoyed my time working for such a great company.

1. Great employee oriented company, consistently in the best companies to work for in the US and world 2. Competitive salaries 3. Cost of living in Memphis suburbs is low, quality if life very nice including good/great schools. 4. Excellent work-life balance 5. Pension plan
Great environment, i learned alot in the short amount of time that I was there and hope to be working for them full time when I graduate

They invest in their employees and promote from within.  The have a people, service, profit motto that they live and breath-if you hire the right people and treat them well, they will give exceptional service to the customer which brings in the profit.  Some of the best mentors in my career were at FedEx.
decent insurance, lots of vacation and sick time

The upper level management is making great decisions.  The company is working on and developing great new opportunities and strengths for itself.  In the future I am confident that the growth and market share will increase for FedEx.
Very family oriented company. Truly take care of their employee. The management does think of families their decision affects. Team members are very friendly.
Good benefits, training, and opportunities for career advancement
cons: Usually would have to work early early mornings or evenings at the airport. No real day jobs and not much opportunity to go full-time unless you moved.

expectations were very unrealistic. Its impossible to do 45 stops in 35 minutes all spread out in the snow. Theres no concern for your safety just get it done. And if you dont kiss up to the managers get ready for alot of uncalled for write ups that you see other people get away with on a everyday basis.
A lot of pressure to make sure packages were on time and customers were treated with ultimate respect. Not negative pressure, mostly pressure you put on yourself to not let anyone down.
Big company, not many people want to give up excellent quality of life - the end result being not many growth opportunities.
Very strict working hours.  Alot of work to handle on a daily basis.  Can be very stressfull
For most sales positions you will be required to move to a new state.

scheduled to work every holiday (decent compensation for this), actual pay isn't that great, the heat has been broken on and off since I started in 2015, a lot of inconsistency in policy and procedure application,
Everything boils down to how management impacts you.  I can say that most of the managers I have had at FedEx have been great.
Technology is not cutting edge. Changes are very slow. The salary is not keeping up with the market. In some department their is lack of innovation.
Hourly employees work extremely hard but are not paid wages that reflect their worth

review: Hard to move up and promote.
Overall a good company to work for
Great company, good benefits, forward thinking
pros: Decent benefits, great work/life balance, good training opportunities. Good opportunities to change to another team depending on where you are located.
Fedex has great employee and insurance benefits. For material handler, this should only be a part time job unless a part time job is all you're looking for
Good way to earn money part time.  Especially if you are a student or you have other requirements of your time.
The name and the history of the company are inspiring.  It has grown very fast.
Great working environment, fantastic experience with the coworkers, and fabulous management style.
Flexible hours, tuition reimbursement. I like that it is a fast paced environment. It is great place to work for a part-time job. Excellent benefits!
Great benefits and and retirement plan. The hours are ok. With the right schedule you don't work weekends and you get paid holidays off.
Benifits are great and flexible for students.  Tuition reimbursment program is an excellent benifit.  When the economy was down FedEx still provided a secure work setting.

cons: They use outdated technology stacks, too many people have worked at FedEx for too long and resist change. The development / deployment lifecycle is very long and the velocity is low and the defect rate is medium to high.

You will only only get about 4 hours per day/ night if you are lucky. Christmas is about the only time you will get more hours. You can always ask for more hours, but odds are, it's only going to be on the weekends.

uncaring management.  Sometimes, situations happen that are beyond our control and prevent us from coming to work on time.  Although, I do understand that reporting to work and on time is a requirement of the job.

The leadership and management below Fred Smith need to get their heads out of their butts and realize the unnecessary stress that they put on their Sales folks.  They do not put their people first, they do not care about their customers.....all they care about is their Stockholders, Wall Street and where the leadership is going to go for President's Club on the backs of their sales people.  The company has grown too fast and the wrong people are in charge and too many good people have gone.
You have to work overtime usually in order to complete since the job is extremely heavy and there are tons of stuffs you have to do in order to complete the daily task.

Never more than 20 hours a week. You have to give up your personal life for overtime if you are picked.
110 Degree warehouse in the summer.  The holidays are non-existant because we are providing a service that is stressed during those times.
Very busy during holiday season and overtime is mandated. Very strict about attendance and tardiness.  You are marked down on your review if you use sick time.
FedEx sometimes loses focus on their goals and chases the competition.  At times it drives its people harder and longer than needed.  Upward mobility is usually limited unless you are in Memphis.

review: FedEx is a great place to work.
i am satisified with my career at fedex

pros: The company pillars are People, Service, Profit. FedEx cares about its team members above all else, then providing the utmost service levels possible, and lastly profitable. This should tell you a lot about them as an employer and I would recommend working with FedEx.

FedEx offers a broad range of career opportunities providing for lateral and promotional moves.

it has been a good place to work for. i really like the atmosphere there and the managment are very nice.

Good pay for less hours compared to other part-time jobs

The job itself is not very challenging and therefore not really rewarding. Compensation is not there and the bonus system is a fraud.
it can be very demanding at times and the hours can be very long and sometimes last 10-14 hours.

Management talks to you like a child and makes every attempt to make you feel inadiquate no matter how good of a job you do. Even though many new oppertunities open up if your not a blood relitive of Sr. empolyees you will not get the job. Not enough parking for employees and you must park blocks away on the street with tractor trailors almost running into your vehical. They have been advertising for hiring  nonstop sense I began there in 2006, this high turnover in workers should tell you something about the enviorment.
Intensity and heat along with sweat is hard to deal with
Too many internal procedures to follow.  This causes you to work more hours per week than you really need to.
Pay could be better but that is made up for by all of the other great aspects of the company
pay not in line with with the fast paced work having to work split shifts in order to get enough hours was very hard to do

review: Work environment and culture is great, but salary is low and not enough growth opportunities.

pros: One of the most admired companies with global reputation and strong C-level leadership.

Limited supervising and easy to learn hands on skills.
Great American story.   Lots of teamwork and comrades..sometimes you run across lazy employees but good manager address this accordingly

Out on my own and get work at my own pace.  Can get the job done quick.

Hours based on work load.

EVERYONE is overworked.
Management is understaffed and usually frustrated as a result.
Senior management is far removed from the operation and doesn't have a clue what goes on daily (Although they think they do).
Sometimes people don't show and it more work on others holidays are really busy and at times you may not get the work done fast enough

review: Ehh. Workload high, manager showed favoritism, didn't care about your personal responsibilities.

Yard Jockey,  looking to promote to management.

pros: Got alot of overtime. Insurance was good and cheap. Can't really think of anything else to say about pros of the company.

Truly care about their people
Stability
Longevity
Mobility
Horrible place to work.
As secure a job as you can get in todays environment. Opportunities exist for internal job movement when things are going good.
World Class projects on which to work, a company with which you can be proud, and good people with whom to work.
Fairly easy to get hired due to big turnover rate. Best insurance I have seen in a long time.

full benefits and vacation time, start off as part time and become full-time very quickly, always overtime available, good raises

Many opportunities for growth 
You learn about 
Depend on what you do the task will be easy to handle and a breeze to master in. Package handler
cons:
The workload was entirely too high. Impossible to complete the work in your 8 hour day and even with overtime, it was still impossible unless you stayed till 8-9pm, sometimes later. 

Manager didn't care if you had a child that needed to be picked up a certain time. But she always ran out of the door to pick up her pet dog by 6. 

I can go on and on.
Too Stable for a young person like myself. I am looking to relocate and it is exceptionally difficult. Not the company's fault exactly, but frustrating.

If your under 10 years with the company you have no seniority.  When you turn in your vacation forget about summers. You get split days off. No balance with work and home life. If you call out sick your manager for sure will ride you when you return. If you get into an accident and you hurt someone your fired. If you have 3 related vehicle accidents, or any ocurrence with your vehicle your fired.  Managers reviews don't mean a thing. If your part time you can be sent home after 3 hours. people transfering in your department from other department will bump you after six months so if your new forget it.  Managers are uneducated locker room mentality idiots. No continuous education for upper level staff. Trucks are terrible and unsafe. Tractor trailers are old seats with terrible springs and air. Lots of problems with back and knees.
Ironically, some of the positives outlined above - job security makes people complacent and examples of seat-warmers are abundant.
Complex company that takes a while to learn and is challenging to navigate.
I seam to have been passed up over and over again due to being over 40. Takes about a year to qualify for the medical insurance. Wages were OK. Not the worst but surly not the best.

Crazy hours around Christmas, must take vacation days in week long increments until you're there 10 years, some favoritism, cannot transfer to international jobs, pilots have incredible benefits that other employees are denied

start off as part time depending on open full time positions
Working on the doc in the hot weather or cold weather

review: Good Part Time Job, Difficult Full Time Job

PSP is just a slogan -- it's the same as other corporate cultures
Experience as Import Agent And Import Coordinator _Indianapolis location
good place to work overall. i recommend it
pros:

Good money for unskilled labor
The hours were perfect for a night owl like me

There are also pretty good medical and 401k benefits.
Good continued training opportunities amd free broker licenses.
good benefits like pay, health care, retirement programs that are easy to join and provide lots of benefits when you are old
cons:
Incredibly slow pay progression, you will never top out  (29$+)

Strong likelihood of injury

None I am aware of.

Very hard on your body.
Creepy cult-like brainwashed mentality is widespread among the workers... Seriously, these people take company loyalty to a whole new level.
I'd go home caked with dirt and dust every night.
So many people quite because our manager was incredibly short tempered that we were understaffed for quite a while. 
Almost impossible to advance very far because nobody retires anymore.

1) FedEx earnings estimates were down (due to weak global economy)
2) The CEO, Fred Smith, nearly doubled his salary, and Rob Carter, CEO of FedEx Services, accepted an 80% raise.

Does this sound like they care about you the worker, or you the stockholder?

all roads lead to memphis. there is a chance to make moves up if you are willing to move every two years to lots of large cities around the world

review: Hard work, good part time pay
If only they gave enough hours
Working at FedEx World Tech Center.
date_position: Jan 21, 2018 - Fed Ex Ground Package Handler
pros: No Pros. U will b treated like u work in a sweat shop. If u r injured it will b deemed preventable and b yr fault. Mgt expects u to wrk xtra hrs when others r off.  Yr hrs will not b consistent and will be cut when mgt doesn't need u.  Training for yr job is terrible or doesn't happen.
Not many companies provide FULL benefits for part time employment.
FedEx cares about the employees. There are opportunities to work in various areas and bits of training to be had. Layoffs are not a part of the culture if possible.
Fun work environment, great part time pay, good for part time work and college classes, tuition assistance is a great plus
Active job, meet new and interact with people. Great benefits to include tuition assistance. Great part-time hours and hourly wage.
Positive atmosphere, stress on safety, flexible hours. quick pay raises
Very people focused, a really stable unique industry. The intern program is top notch
Working as a team with on-call specialists and other co-workers at the office. The environment was very stress-free.
Great and affordable insurance for individuals or for family, career advancements to move up in the company and great management that listens and tries to help there employees.
In my area, you get paid about twice minimum wage. Not bad for unskilled labor.
cons: Fedex is doing poorly but employees shouldn't b treated so badly.  FX needs to return to offering psychological incentives, treat their frontline employees better. U only hear frm mgt. when u make a mistake.  Very stressful, very low morale exists and it impacts yr personal life.

Early hours, only 20-24 hours per week, no chance for overtime, hard physical labor, can be stressful but rewarding, manages really stress timeframe.
Can be overwhelming at times trying to meet pick-up times. Holiday season can be tiresome and expect to work late hours.

Not enough hours 11-14 a week. You can get sent home after an hour and a half of work. this sucks if you have to wake up early in the morning (like 4am). You have to wait a year before you get benefits.
Its a huge company that has all the bureaucracy of it. They don't let you do jumpseat like in castaway anymore. Salary is not competitive for entry level developers
12 hour shifts can be exhausted during 3 day work periods. Only getting an hour break for a 12 hour shift.
Lack of full time postions. If part time is your thing this is the place for you. Would wish they offered more full time positions.

Unreliable hours. Unreliable managers. Unreliable Equipment. More often than not, I was cut due to lack of work. More often than not I couldn't get my boss' attention off his tejano music video to do more than point out what chute was 75% or 100% full.  This is not a place for the slow, weak, or those easily bored. There's  no room to advance as they hire outside. They never ASK anyway.

review: Mostly positive, rough at times, but that comes with any job.
Great company ethic to it's people, customers, and value proposition.
A really Frustrating experience. FedEx don't value your qualification and expertize
A company you truly want to retire from.
pros: FedEx is a solid company with a great reputation. There is/was a wealth of talented individuals from whom you can learn. As with any large company, some people are extremely easy to get along with and some aren't. Good pay and benefits.

Pure corporate structure with an emphasis on business. Great place to excel and make a decent paycheck.
Ethical company with a work life balance.  As a professional staff member you have give and take on both side.  Balance, not perfection is the goal.

Great company benefits. Raises are minimal at 2 percent a year so you are there for the benefits not the pay.
The teammates are all friendly there is a great work environment. The HR staff is the best anywhere and are very knowledgeable on all aspects of employment.

cons: Afraid the People-Service-Profit philosophy is being replaced by Profit-Service-Profit.

After having  a masters and couple of years IT experience failed to get a decent job within Fedex. and ultiamtely end up in quit and I have landed in a IT job with  a staring salary of 70 K.I truely wasted my valuable 4 years with Fedex
Since raises and pay are minimal job is not for someone who needs to make the money for the head of household.
While employed there I did not find any cons to speak of. Others complained of lack of parking space close to the building.
I truly cannot think of any cons in FedEx it is been a wonderful experience.

review: Great people, slow development and corporate processes
Hard to advance past this part time job
A great experience with opportunity to grow
great company, not much negative to say
pros: Great technology company, full benefits, retirement pension, pays very well.  Freedom to perform job with empowerment to execute as needed.
Good flexibility with Work and Life Balance, great salaries, friendly diverse work staff.  Flexible in allowing some work from home.

Great benefits, food was catered by Chic Fila and other local businesses,  2 weeks paid time off.
ewarding work, free training, free travel, great people, desire to modernize and advance

various opportunities career changes within the company. strong "people first" culture. Laid back culture, business casual, strong commitment to community service. Flexible work schedule and family friendly environment
FedEx is a great place to work.  They have many people in the department working many exciting projects.
Talented peers, good work/life balance, challenging projects, fair compensation, and the opportunity to transition into other fields.
Fantastic corporate culture, wonderful brand, ability to interact and learn from senior mgmt
cons: I honestly don't have any cons.  I had an amazing job with the best management.  You have to be flexible and handle stress well.  That's corporate America.

Alot of older people who can't pull their load of work. Too many stubborn and lazy people.
Very slow processes, large code-base is hard to change, pay is slightly low

Limited levels of promotion for professionals, very little upward mobility and growth, performance management very subjective, even in new system. Maternity leave only 5 weeks of partial pay

Promotional opportunities are not plentiful, just not much turn over from those above.  And yearly salary increases are ok, but nothing that will change your life

review: FedEx is not a good company.
Fast pace work place with a fair amount of responsibility, and work ethic learning experience.
Great place to work while in school or seeking a second source of income
pros: Good Benefits and 401K match was decent. The brand is well known and a common name in the industry.  There are many locations to seek employment.
Good leadership, and management, everyone is friendly and knowledgeable about what needs to get done for things to operate smoothly in a timely fashion.
Stability and opportunity to advance
Great pension plan for all the old timers, if you got hired after 1990, not good at all.   Pays very well compare to UPS or Ontrac.
Lots of internal growth, creativity to try your own processes and solutions in the market.  Lots of upward mobility.

Nice, friendly people. Learning opportunities. Lots of opportunities for career advancements like P2L (Lead roles), L2M(manager roles), Purple Pipeline(Director role) and so on. Great salary for the location.
Well i've been doing it for quite a while despite all the other jobs and offers i've had. This is one i can't seem to bring myself to leave. Therefore, it must be a good place to work

cons: Health Insurance is not what it used to be,  Insane amount of hours and no lunch allowed if you are in management and the pay is peanuts compared to the amount of work you do. FedEx has a habbit of understaffing to hit operational metrics but never shows it's employees the truth about if their operation is making or losing money. They are rude to customers, overcharge them for anything they can and damage alot of shipments. Additionally, their is poor top down communication and little to no cross communication from the different departments.
Significant amount of volume for only 4 employees (one manager) included trucks full of tires, boxes of paper, and heavy axles

Senior leadership with antiquated view of management and sales philosophy. Pay not inline with market value. Advancement opportunity ends at district manager unless you REALLY become a sycophant and play the game.
Its all about the bottom line and the new 401k plan is not as good as the old pension plan.
Company is making more money now than anytime else in the history of FedEx, yet driver, operations, sales, and manager salaries have remained stagnant.
Laid back culture, low performers can keep the job, few holidays (no black friday, only one day of Christmas), old technology stack (many systems are still legacy)
If they outweighed the pros, I would have left a long time ago.

Minimal career advancement oppertunities unless you are willing to relocate within the company. To focused on the negative rather than mixing in some positive. Makes everyone fear for the potential loss of their job.
Only downside is they don't always pay you on what you sell.  Health benefits aren't the greatest.

I started after one of the last cost of living increases, and pay rates were frozen for a while before they were decreased. It took the rest of my time with the company to get back to where I'd started when I was hired.

review: A great company to work for. Great benefits and very good personnel policies

It's a great company to work for.
pros: Great benefits, good amount of vacation time. Interesting work with the opportunity to meet people from all over the world.
People friendly, great team spirit, Good benefits. Management is serious about keeping employee morale up. One of the best companies to work for.

Always busy which I like. Promote inside the company. Night shift isn't as bad as everyone makes it seem.

Give you great hours if wanted. Not on a point system . Give you opportunities to bid on a different job description to work your way up with the company. Offer car insurance .

cons: long hrs especially during the holidays. the supervisors are arrogant and pompous jerks. everyone is for themselves, so do your job and go home and have a drink.

Boring isn't a strong enough word to describe the work.  I had days where even after 9 hours of sleep the night prior, I would still have to struggle so hard to stay awake that it was physically painful.  The environment is horribly stale.  Quiet.  No decorations.  The work experience is a drudgery grind.

And this would be fine, if employees were allowed to engage in periodic distraction.  A glance at something on the web now and then is enough to keep the brain awake.  Consider also that you're given hard metrics on productivity, so it really shouldn't be a problem if you stay within them.

But no distractions of any kind are officially permissible except for listening to music through headphones.  Doing absolutely anything else with your time while in the office provokes politics.  You could produce the highest numbers in the office and then get in trouble for being unproductive for 10 minutes - not exaggeration, this literally happened.

The regional manager is also horribly obsessive-compulsive - once demanding that my co-worker put his monitor in the same position on his desk as everyone else on the cubicle block, even though doing so aggravated his carpal tunnel.  

The politics are ridiculous.  Favoritism runs deep and rampant.  Upper management will create rules just to bully and micromanage certain employees they don't like, while nothing is enforced on others.  Most of the favorites were people who were barely productive, and spent most of their time trying to get productive employees in trouble for sport.  And the excessively detailed rules created the perfect environment for bullying to take place.

There was one clique in particular who produced the lowest numbers in the office, worked several hours of overtime every day even during periods where anybody else would get written up for clocking out 1 minute past 8 hours, and they would pick on people relentlessly.  They would rotate targets for harassment, and take turns walking past their target's desk periodically to see what they were doing.  If it was anything other than focusing exclusively on work, they would immediately complain, and that person would get written up.  This was an ongoing state of affairs for all 7 years I worked in that office.

Also, any communication regarding pay or the value of your work from corporate was always extremely insulting.  Best example:  there is a fundraising drive every year for United Way.  Every year they show a promotional video.  One year, they had one of the company's top executives introduce the video by saying "We're all feeling the effects of the economic recession", while wearing his immaculate suit and politician's smile.  They then proceeded to show a little documentary bit about how *one of our own co-workers* didn't make enough money to take care of her kid, and how United Way helped her to make ends meet.  And then asked us to donate...
The hours of work would cause me to stay asleep all night simply so I can make it to work on time. You have to be disciplined at managing your schedule and your work life.

Systematically they have removed all the old Kinko's upper management.  
Way too focused on immediate profit rather than growing the customer base. 
Stores are understaffed and employees are overworked.
All of the creativity and innovation has been quashed and replaced with corporate mandates.

Morale is pretty bad these days, given recent layoffs (which seemed pretty random) and last year's pay cuts. Lots of corporate Rah! Rah! marketing programs, emails, posters which for most of us actually are very counter-productive. For the 12th time in 13 years FedEx was voted in Forbes' Top 100 Places to Work. The primary reason given that FedEx is so fantastic: this year we get back half of the 401K match they took away with our pay cuts last year. They had just beefed up the match the year before to compensate us for ditching the pension!

Depending on where you work, you may be plagued with endless meetings. Very often meetings are held not to get input from participants but to disseminate information that could be easily distributed with an email.

There is little room for advancement, in particular technical advancement. The Advisor positions which were created years back might have been used for a more advanced technical position, at least in technical groups, but they are primarily political in nature. Every 'Principal' position - the highest level non-management job - was filled by the buddy system, which is rampant in my particular org.

There is a bit of a hivemind here, and individual thinkers are unlikely to prosper. Incompetent and toeing the party line will get you farther than making waves for improvement. Mediocrity is rewarded, while innovative thinking is a crapshoot.

There are way too many corporate initiatives, and the company is forever paying some consulting firm gadzillions of dollars to recommend one or the other course of action, but we rarely have follow-through. It keeps these initiatives from doing any real harm, but it wastes a lot of resources along the way.

Things are beginning to sort themselves out, but in the meanwhile the company is bleeding talent and slowly filling itself with the wrong kind of "lifers."

cons: FedEx is actually not just a single company--- it's a group of operating companies that "operate independently, compete collectively". Despite efforts to overcome it, there is still a tendency toward "silos" and being territorial at all levels. Having personnel headquarters in Memphis has become an increasing liability since it is a decaying city with a lot of crime, ineffective leadership, high property and sales tax rates, terrible traffic and failing public schools. The great majority of employees are here because they're either from here or they have ties here (family nearby, etc), they are careful about where they buy a home, and they are willing to fork over the money to send their kids to private schools. This could be a good place for a young, childless person, especially someone interested in the arts, to put in two or three years but overall, this is not a particularly innovative or nimble company; there's a lot of "this is how we've always done it".

FedEx was a great place to work.  When I came to work for this company, I truly believed that it was an organization that cared about their employees.  I thought it was a company where I could advance, grow and use the full range of my educational abillities.  Unfortunately, after working for the company for almost 5 years,  I have discovered that things are changing greatly at FedEx.   FedEx is not a company that cares about their employees.  I understand that the economic conditions are impacting this organization. However, I was very disappointed when the news revealed that I would be receiving a pay deduction before I was aware. To make matters worse, I opened an e-mail to read about the changes that would be effective immediately. I had to call my manager for clarification. This information was not proactively provided to me.  What a disappointment? Did the company care about me? I wanted notification so that I could make the necessary adjustments and pay. To add insult to injury, the press release said that the pay deduction would be permenant and I would not receive a merit increase in 2009.  I would be a little more accepting if the company was committed to bringing me back up to the my current salary level after the economic situation improves. There was no commitment.  Health insurance costs continue to increase as well.

I cannot think of a good reason to work for FedEx, now.

Political.  Not much standardization for the sales force i.e., a type of sink or swim environment with tools flying at us that are not properly tested before we get them.  These take up time we dont have but are required to use, only to have the next new thing be dumped on us a few weeks later.  It is like a contest to see who can make a name for themselves by coming up with a new technique and after that we have to work out the bugs.  By that time, another tool or training will be required.      We supposedly are given warm leads, but approx 40% of the spreadsheet are companies out of business, havent shipped in over 10 years, etc.  To close the sale we have to use a process, which means if a customer wants to ship with us the same day we call, we cannot close it unless we have a minimum of 3 calls.  AND we have to move the sale through a "certainty' rating, which means  we have to log the close as 25% sure, then 50% sure, then 75%, 90% then close it.   Many dont do it this way and just make sure they have the minimum 3 calls.  No one seems to believe that an inside sasales professional can know if the customer is wanting to ship in one or 2 calls.  Also, we now have a phone system that allows management to listen to our calls so there is the Big Brother aspect.  

Managers play favorites and there is no recourse to this as the manager network is tight.  I.e., it would do no good to report one as blatantly applying the rules according to their personal preferences vs. what is fair and equitable.  

The sales job requires a minutia of extraneous tasks in additional to actual selling.  The systems we have are not user friendly and it requires using 4-5 places to find all the information necessary to track our calls, pull up information about the customer and track the customer's shipping for closes.  There is a lag time to seeing how a customer is shipping, we have to wait 1-2 days to get pricing approved for them, etc.  And after we bring on an account and grow it, we then have to give it to the field sales reps who usually have not done a single thing to work the account.  Any objections will be answered with:  "It's the right thing for the customer."   Everyone in sales knows this is an untruth.   The other thing about field sales is FedEx seems to have a preference for hiring outside for field and had no problem hiring 70 layed off DHL reps which took promotional opportunities away from internal employees.    Speaking of promotional opportunities, 
promotional opportunities are largely dependent on the relationship with your manager.  So know what to kiss and when.

Well it got to be that my route became so busy that I was working 12 hour days most of the time but only being paid for 8. At times I wasn't even making minimum wage due to the hours I was working. I probably didn't deliver 5 packages in my 4 years of service due to weather and I never called in sick once.  I did complain because there was a discrimination of whites at our FedEx and the handlers would come in late and then sit around and talk.  I was asked many times during holidays to clock out during delivery so I didn't go over federal guidelines for drive time. I also didn't get paid all the time from my first route contractor. I always did as I was told.  Then just two weeks ago I was pulled for a random drug test and I failed for marijuana.  I do not see how I could of failed, I have been around it but I am not a smoker.  I was told too bad, instantly fired by FedEx not my contractor boss.  I was then blacklisted from FedEx forever.  My heart was tore out. I worked my butt off for FedEx even though I was really not working for them but for a contractor without benefits, holiday pay or vacation time.  All this and I am still upset about not working at FedEx, hence still the #3 rating.
More reporting than selling.  Can be micro-managed depending on who your manager and director are.
Sometimes "Silo" thinking and operating from the various operating companies hampers development and creativity. Politically and socially conservative - a very Republican-leaning company.

Sometimes, it seems they value quantity far more than quality. When we load trailers we sometimes get overloaded and you can easily get written up for not meeting their goals for the day. Normally, hitting the goal is handling and scanning 1 box every 7 seconds. This may not seem hard, but when the boxes coming down the chutes jam, you have to walk to the jam, break it, and hope that boxes don't spread all throughout the truck trailer. Sometimes labels are smeared and don't scan properly or at all. Little to no help most of the time, making the 1 box every 7 seconds hard at times. Management can sometimes treat you like a number, which working at a factory-like facility where you are easily replaced... Maybe that's not a con but more a norm sadly. Prepare to feel pain, whether it cuts, bruises or knots from where boxes ranging from 5 lbs. to 150 lbs. attack you.
As a worker hired under the grandfather clause, I was approached to join the Union.

It’s very difficult to review FedEx and no one opinion can be generalized to reflect how this company works.  Being a large company it in a way works like the world itself.  There are some good parts that make you proud and there are some parts that will totally annoy and drive you out of the company.  So opinions will largely depend on which part do you face the most.  On overall level and it’s a well respected company led by a visionary. It’s in a good position in the industry as there are high barriers to entry especially on the Express and Ground business.   FedEx being in logistic domain is operationally driven company and luckily the management and systems are very strong where they should be.  If you work in the operation area this is a best place to work as company’s focus as well as all the services including IT are dominant in this area. However, if you work in shared services like Marketing or Sales this may seem like a terrible place as everything seems inferior in this area, management, systems.  FedEx is well known for path breaking advances in IT, but if you are in Services area, the IT support is abysmal.

Experience and opinion of FedEx are also largely shaped by individuals and their career aspirations.  For many folks, working in a stable company and living in an inexpensive place is more important and this place is ideal for them.  But if you are advanced degree holder looking for a good career growth this is not the place for you.  Career growth and  promotions especially in the management depend upon open position.  For every promotion you will have to apply for the position and compete with many individuals.  So even if you perform at the highest level there is no guarantee that you will get promoted as there may not be open positions and even if there is one, 20-30 people may be vying for the same job.  Many times the individual is chosen before all the interviews take place and then many people interview just so that hiring manager can complete the formality. 
This also leads a good point, being a large company the experience of FedEx largely depends on the Vice Presidents of the area.  If you are stuck in a group with ineffective or politically motivated VP, then you are out of luck.  I know of a VP who used to promote all his friends or well wishers or other reasons which are more speculations that known facts so not worth mentioning.  Most of his promotion decisions bombed but it still goes on.  He used to conduct interview even for regular promotions with no additional responsibility and give job to someone he likes and tell others that they didn’t interview well.   At the same time I also know of VPs who always strived to do what is right.

Compensation, you will be provided a fair wage, however you will never get wealthy, yet upper level management makes a tremendous amount of money when compared to front line management. Major compensation issues in regard to being equally fair accross the board. The culture has changed, before the "merger" with RPS, the company truly put the employees first and followed the policy  of treat your employees well, and in turn your employees will provide the best possible service to our customers, and therefore profitability will follow. The policy worked for years but when the merger happened the employees were no longer treated with respect and were treated as if they were a liability that could be replaced on a whim. Also management by intimidation has become the culture of the day, with the new performance review system and the sales professionals and sales manager no longer have the empowerment to make decisions in which they could have made prior to 1999, and no longer able to run their perticular district or region as they wanted to. In the beginning the mantra was to run each territory/district/ region as it was the sales persons personal business, that is no longer an option.

Promotions(they rarely promote within the company, if you are lucky enough to do so, it takes a loooong time, and barely a raise), raises suck, no company perks besides 75% off Express shipments, if you are "full time" you will be given about 30 hours(don't expect 40), the training SUCKS terribly...be prepared to learn EVERYTHING on your own as it happens.

Fedex is currently in stupid/confused mode. They are buying up other transportation companies while taking their focus off the part of the company that started the whole show. Express volumes are way down due to sales shifting pkgs to Fedex Ground. They are mothballing aircraft and keeping vehicles well passed their service life. I would love to show pictures of the rusted piece of crap truck we just got rid. I'm sure investors would be interested in knowing what's really going on at Fedex. They take vehicles from station that some coffee dog in Memphis says the station doesn't need even though he/she doesn't have a friggin clue what the stations vehicle needs are. They put 2 wheel drive vehicles in parts of the country that need 4 wheel drive. Having 4 wheel drive vehicles is what separates us from the competition but upper management is too stupid to figure it out. The give us a raise and then raise our rates. They have a spending freeze so it's hard to get new uniforms. I've had the same shirts for a decade. If you are young and a hard worker and don't mind being stressed all the time Fedex is for you. You will learn to hate driving. I mean despise driving. Remember those weekend drives you took with your significant other? Say goodbye to them. You will not want to leave your home your days off. Christmas? Don't even get me started. You will come to hate your favorite holiday and will only put up with it for the sake of your kids. 20 years of my life wasted but they paid for my kids and my wife was able to be a stay home mom. So, it is what it is. Most of the employees I work with are smokers and alcoholics.

It's basically a data entry job, don't let the title fool you. The pay is low, not a job for college graduates.   There are around 30 other people doing the same thing as you so seniority is going to play a big role in promotions.  They start you at around $14 or $15 per hour.  And you get like 2% raise each year, so you do the math. You will have to put in 4+ years just to get $1 raise.  There are other reviews here that proves it could be worse than the example i gave you.  At these kind of pay, a single person cannot survive since rent alone is around $1,000 + utilities for a studio.  This job is for kids living with parents or for people with a significant other that is making the big money.  How does the company get away with paying so low? 
They hire minorities(some can't even speak proper English) who would otherwise have a hard time finding a job.  If you are a white person, don't bother applying to Sr. Entry coordinator positions at the LA/Torrance (soon to move to Gardena) location because they have filled these low level jobs with minorities. Great move by the senior management at the HQ in Memphis.  They can claim to be a equal opportunity employer saying they have this many minorities in the company and this many minorities in management.  But if you look deeper into the company, you will see the minorities are at the very bottom in job level and pay.  The higher you go, the whiter it gets.  They have minorities in management positions at this LA locations, but these supervisor/managers are just puppets.  They have no authority over anything.  All the decisions are made in Memphis.  Again, don't expect to come in a get a promotion anytime soon.  Prepare to put in years at these wages since there are already many people in line ahead of you.

With this company being a Fortune 50 company, you'd expect more from it, but don't get your hopes up.  This is the biggest employer in Memphis so they pretty much can treat their employees any way they want and we'd have to put up with it.  The Vacation and Benefits are outdated as compared to other companies of it's size.  Management is great at saying things that sound good without any follow through. All the systems are old and outdated and the one new system they have promoted as a "savior" has landed is the biggest thud in history.   The new system makes our job 5x harder because it just will not work. So we're still being told to work harder even though we have bad tools to work with. 

The sales dept has been allowed the run of the company. They treat everyone they come in contact with horribly and the department has no backbone to stand up to them.  They will consider you their personal concierge.

If you're looking for opportunities to move up. Don't join.  The opportunities here are few and very far between.  There are a bunch of people who are sitting in positions, who have been in the same position for 20 years,  and plan to retire in those same positions, blocking the way for any movement.  You have others that don't want to be here, but are waiting for another buyout to leave.  Even applying for internal positions is very political.  In some cases if you want to even be considered for the job, you have to go and talk to the manager and  kiss up to them  a little otherwise your resume won't even be called for an interview. Even if you're highly qualified.  Most areas would rather fly someone in for a job than promote from within the company.
