Just about everything else. The management is absolutely the worst I've ever seen. The senior manager needs to be replaced ASAP. She is running that place into the ground and has been for years. She is vindictive, manipulative, and will find a way to get rid of you if you disagree with her in any capacity. If you make her mad enough, she'll completely make something up to try and get you fired. The employees there have seen it happen multiple times. Her and the majority of management do not care about any of the employees or their well being. Favoritism is an issue as well. 
The pay is laughable. They try to call the job a call center, though nothing about it is like a call center. They pay low wages because they consider it one, although new hires get hired on now making more than the supervisors even do, or the employees that have worked there for 15+ years. The senior manager is trying to force all the tenured employees out the door so that she can replace them with people that don't question her and are younger and more productive. 
The workload is insane. They have mismanaged things so badly that employees are having to take on literally 4X the normal amount of work, and management doesn't do anything about it because they know that "it'll get done one way or another".  The list goes on and on. Turnover and attrition are at an all time high. People are quitting right and left. 
 Run so far away from this circus and go work for someone who values you. Go work for any other branch of FedEx even.  You will also have absolutely no work life balance. Expect to work massive amounts of overtime because there is so much work constantly.

-not a good place to work if you like seeing your family. 50 hour work weeks are the norm with no end in sight.
- new hires have no desk to sit at and are forced to sit in a training room by themselves until the next disgruntled employee walks out, freeing up a desk
-new web based systems are being forced on the agents and they crash hourly because the servers aren't strong enough 
-new phone system is a joke. Customers aren't even able to leave a message. Team leads are forced to micromanage employees every second of the day. Literally, you have to specify what you are doing when you get up. If you get up to go to the bathroom, your team lead may be forced to stop what he or she is doing to take a call.
-team leads are stretched so thin that they can't even be expected to get to all of their tasks.
-team leads are grossly underpaid. 
-feelings of hopelessness among leadership (leads and managers) because of how the senior manager is running the place.
-team leads and managers aren't allowed to meet with senior manager's boss without senior manager present. No real feedback can ever be given because of this and it creates a real "keep your head below the parapet" mentality 
-senior manager will lie to make herself look good
-senior manager avoids coming out of her office most of the day
-very few career advancement opportunities

Stagnant, compartmentalized, go nowhere job.  If you want a job that you can sit in for the next 40 years and do the same thing day in and day out, this is the place for You! Management is useless, they will never have your back and cower to sales every chance they get.  You will only get a promotion after working there about 10 years and that will be only if HR makes them because you're maxing out the salary grade.  The only other way you're getting promoted is if you're on project work, but the catch is, they pick the same people (favorites) to do project work over and over.  So don't bet on that.  The work is demeaning and draining every second of everyday!  Sales will literally treat you like dirt under their feet.  They will belittle you, harass you, and treat you down right unprofessionally without repercussions and in most cases your manager will not have your back or defend you or the team in any way. Finally, because of most of the things I've mentioned and more I didn't, we have had a FLOOD of people leaving the department which makes more and more work and stress for the people who remain since they can't hire people fast enough. Even when people are hired, it take at least 6mos to a year to get up to speed in order to effectively help with the workload.

FedEx does not provide adequate benefits to a majority of the employees.  Some Workgroups do have adequate benefits.  The executive management group has an excellent pay, retirement, and bonuses.  There retirements benefits are outstanding, retirement pay, and retirement medical.  

As for the majority of employees the pay is inadequate, the health insurance is sold to the employees for a high price with very poor coverage.  The traditional pension plan was discontinued, and frozen.  They have a very inadequate cash Pension Plan that will pay a minimum token amount when the employee leaves after 20 years.  It is based on your salary and time in service, and applied to a company account every three months with a interest rate of 1% every three months.  That ADDS up to 4% the year, and you do not control the money in the account.  It is controlled by the company.  

Many of the retirees are struggling with the health insurance.  The retirees have to pay $700 to $1,000 a month for coverage for two people.  This is no better than Cobra coverage.  

Many people go to work for large companies for the benefits,  health insurance and retirement knowing that this was promised at the beginning of their employment with this company.  

FedEx is very good with public relations they have the means and the money to make the story sound good.  They also are very good of promising many things.  But to is all smoke and mirrors.

Basically you have long time employees hanging on in their positions which clearly have no desire to improve themselves or the company. They started in an office and will end their career in the office and don't really understand air or ocean freight. For a freight forwarder I have never been around so many people that know so little about transportation or even about other parts of FedEx. Middle and upper mgmt don't seem to travel like they do at other forwarders. At other forwarders you will find very diverse team from all over the world even in hourly and intern positions. Well not here they seem to be all from Memphis. They are clueless what markets need attention to grow business and they seem to run both operations and office environments with minimal employees. The next biggest thing for FTN is to grow Air and Ocean to overtake the competition but, they lack the tools, employees, and leverage with carriers to do this. They also want to utilize Fedex Freight to grow their trucking business. I find this strange because most forwarders don't put their focus in the trucking business. They have no TMS system, nor do they plan on getting one, they seem to like do do things manually. They leave positions open intentinaly to save money. Its a company that wants to be global but thinks local. Find something better.

so as to avoid lawsuits, all discriminatory practices were incredibly subtle; on the surface (e.g., word/communication level), there was no discrimination and allegedly support. However, if you are not African-American (or if you are, but don't "fit"), then the discriminatory behaviors begin. One person was fired because he did not come in to work his shift when he had a 103 fever (proven by a hospital note), even though he had given several hours notice that he was in the hospital. Another was fired because they did not like her clothes (she was harassed daily on her choice of clothing - which was border-line professional: nice pants and a top - and sent home to change until she was fired). I was told to lie on the phone: "tell the customer whatever you have to tell them to get them off the phone". I was not fired, but I was harassed daily, given conflicting instructions from day to day (although I will say that the person "sentenced" to "coach" me started apologizing by the end of day 2 - and it was obvious she was being forced to create a stressful work environment - and it caused her more stress than it did me). All of those fired for "created" reasons (some were fired for legitimate reasons) were white. Those, like me, who were not fired had to "live" with a very hostile environment. One of my friends, a beautiful (inside & out) woman of color, advised me (when I started) to be "invisible - get in, do your work, get out" - hard to do that when I don't have a dark tan.

EXTREMELY DANGEROUS. You will definitely get hurt at this job, it's just a matter of when and how badly. It was crazy seeing how intensely some people were maimed working as package handlers. The job is already stressful.  A trace agent speaks to upset/irate customers all day long, 8-hours a day. It is a division of customer service - but is not customer service.  So you don't even get the nice friendly calls to inquire about services or rates.  You only get the upset customers from calls that have been escalated.  (And the calls are back-to-back ... And you better be on "available" or you have to write an explanation as to why you are not taking calls.) You understand that is part of the job - it is what it is.  However, most of the co-workers are very unprofessional with a fierce, petty, ghetto attitude. Many of them have grown up together and go to the same church and/or live close to each other.  So it is very cliquey. If the non-stop irate calls and the co-workers are not stressful enough, you get no support from the managers.  In fact, they might say they have an open door policy - but that does not mean they are actually willing to listen to any of your concerns or helpful suggestions ... Lest you have a complaint.  They will only preach to you the corporate policies to make you get "on-board" with the program.  Once I had a problem with a manager that kept bullying me.  I mean a manager that treated me like a kindergartner and told me to do things because "she said so".  When I approached the Sr. Mgr. with my concerns, the response was "Let's use this as a coaching opportunity for you".  In other words, the complaint will get nowhere.  So I better shut up and take it.  I realize now the mentality of a large corporation and how management is only there to back each other up.  It's such a shame as I was a hard-working employee that tried to do my best to keep up with the high call volume and consistently be empathetic and helpful to the customers that were in an awful predicament without the delivery of their package.  Other departments at FedEx might be great.  But this particular department has only gone downhill.  It is a nasty cut-throat abusive environment. They expect Trace Reps to be the customer's advocate.  But the management is not there to be the Trace Agent's advocate.  The job is terrible and is always in a "crisis" mode with your taking a beating for FedEx on almost every call.  Yes, that is understood that is what you signed up for.  But the job could be so much more tolerable with sympathetic and supportive managers and less Corporate politics and the ever growing rules that add more burden than assistance to the job/employee itself.  The whole department is a pressure cooker waiting to explode. I would not wish this job on my friends ... buy maybe my worst enemies - Yes.
A little too much politics in the management levels. Make it difficult for a contractor to do his/her  work. Sometimes it was awkward and caused project to be delay unnecessarily.

Pay – Call center wages and is not anywhere near being a call center. 
Call Center – NO. Pay is at call center wages but this is no call center. 
Overtime – Mandatory excessive and extreme overtime.  
Advancement – NO. This is only a job, not a career. There is no opportunity advance. 
Vindictive Workplace – Agents cannot speak up or take time off for fear of retaliation.
Favoritism – Agents are required to "assist" others to get the work done, not their own work, but someone else’s work. 
Turnover – The turnover is high due to low pay and a high-stress work environment.
Systems – The systems are antiquated.

FedEx doesn't follow their own code of business ethics policies and procedures, they are not worth the paper or digital media they are printed on, the words are there for the sake of the shareholders and to help prevent lawsuits!   Sales Managers are given free reign to say and do whatever they want about an employee and fire them on the spot without providing any details or opportunity to defend themselves.  At Will employment does not mean that FedEx Managers can break the law and they are.  Harassment, Hostile work environments, intimidation, disparagement and bullying is rampant and even when you report it Nothing is done....Oh wait something is done-the Manager keeps their job and the employee gets fired.  Discrimination violations are rampant and nobody tells anyone for fear of retaliation and HR is a joke(everyone knows FedEx HR is in place for FedEx Management only and going to HR is career suicide).  Unbelievable-it's still the good ol' boys network!

The schedule is VERY flexible.  If you have to run an errand or leave early for an appointment its fine.  This is a place where management actually cares about its employees.  Recently with the economy going through a rough patch it would have been very easy to layoff people, right before Christmas no less.  Instead, upper management took the biggest salary cuts and reduced our salaries by 5% and no one lost their job.  I eliminated my personal trainer (a luxury item) to make up the difference in pay.  No big deal whatsoever.  I have the ability to work from home if necessary.  This is a very laid back place to work where if you are talented and get your work done on time you will be successful.  People who are self-motivated and hard-working will definitely love this company.  You will be rewarded for your hard work.  I would say about 90% of management is promoted from within the organization.

FedEx is the definition of corporate america.  You are nothing but a number and there are 360,000 employees.  If you are looking for a sales job, this job is not for you.  I spend 80% of my time dealing with non sales issues such as invoice adjustments, tracking packages, software issues, pricing not loaded correctly, ect and 20% of my time selling.  I have been screwed so many times out of bonuses when I bring on an account that is "incorrectly aligned" or does not spend enough money to meet adjustment criteria.  This job looks great on your resume but long term you will realize you spend majority of your time dealing with problems not selling.  But to be fair, it's not that bad if you learn how to play the games and train your customers to utilize the customer service department instead of calling your cell phone every time they have a problem.

review: If you like manual labor, this is a great place to work
Depends on your boss and department...
pros: Good multinational environment and different cultures

Autonomy. 

Tuition Reimbursement.  

Good wage for unskilled labor (great for students)

Paid to exercise.  

Neat logo/uniforms/design.  

Reputable.  

I worked the PM sort alone at a small station through college--scanning and loading an average of about 750 packages in a 2.5 hour period.  You're graded for accuracy each night by comparing your (outbound) scans to the pick up scans done by the CSAs and Couriers--I believe 99.4% was the minimum goal--which means out of 750 packages and documents, you could only miss four to meet goal.  At my station, they don't randomly drug test handlers (unless you operate FedEx vehicles, or there is some type of accident).  Advancing isn't that difficult if you're a competent, hard worker--although FedEx is vehemently anti-union so if you like the idea of being a courier and committing to a company, UPS will pay more in the long run.  Express shipping is extremely expensive, so you're not unloading oddly shaped 140lbs packages all day (although it happens).
Flexible, MNC  environment, friendly culture

Great place to work, the sky is the limit. If you want to educate yourself they offer tuition refunds and encourage people to be their best. Offer great service to their customers.There are enough different jobs at Fedex that if you need a new challenge you can apply for different positions,so you do not need to leave the company for new oppurtunities to grow personally or professionally.

Supportive and people centric organization
Adequate resources to support personal growth
Global MNC exposure
Company who does not care about workers. Smiling in ur face they will stab u in the back.
Very good work culture company wide

FedEx offers a competitive salary and the opportunity for advancement within the organization.  In a relatively short amount of time you are able to progress from a part time employee to a full time manager.  In addition, FedEx offers loads of useful training and college-type courses for personal growth.  Further, the company also offers compensation beyond hourly wage and benefits in the form of college tuition reimbursement, discounts, travel benefits, and more.
training for you to develop
Great team, well established brand name and good work perks
cons: Very demanding and long working hours

In the smaller stations, the amount of work required of you can border on insane.  

Stressful environment.  

They seem to go through low-level managers pretty quickly.  

Can be odd hours (Ramp workers have shifts at 3am, drivers are usually in the door at 6am).
Not much career progression, stuck

overall I'm satisfied , If there was a down sideit would be that  there are not a lot of oppurtunities for the front line employees to move into sales without previous sales expereince. This really impedes people that have been with the company for a long time. I believe there should be a mentorship program that brings the front line employees and sales group together. THere are enough skills test that exist in the world that one would have to write a test see if they are compatiable with sales, if so they should be given a chance to develope those skills without having to leave the company. Overall this is a pet peeve. But this does not distract me from my commitment to the company  or its objectives.
Fierce internal competitions and overly political
If u r rear end kisser this is perfect place for u. But u always be just a number for them.
Very difficult to progress or be promoted.

Some of the detractors of working for FedEx would be the hours; often they can be unpredictable and vary especially when you are part time working towards full time, or when you are a swing driver.  There are also at times issues with staffing and the overloading of work on employees.  One can however understand that to keep the company going and competetive you must keep labor costs lower and productivity higher.
fast pace so need to be ..
Internal processes are extremely slow and outdated. Sales executives are overloaded with extra non productive work continuously

review: No longer a good place to work
Live the "purple promise" and you will satisfy your customers
Comfortable location and tasks are not too difficult but renumeration is bad
Good company for long term career
date_position: Oct 12, 2009 - FedEx Field Sales Senior AE
pros: The people are amazing and the best bunch of people you will ever meet.
People, discounts, pay, air fare/travel benefits
Salary was good for the role. Up to 3 years ago you were encouraged to work independently and take initiative. This changed with acquisition of TNT
Good wedge and few nice people
stable for job security and good environment

Much of the job is autonomous at times. If you can penetrate a key account with a competitor and switch them you'll likely enjoy solid commissions for several quarters. Very good reimbursement for  expenses: car, mileage etc. Solid base pay.
location and friendly / helpful staff
Monday to Friday, not long hours
Great brand recognition?   You don't get the door slammed in your face that's for sure.  If someone won't talk to a FedEx rep, they aren't doing their job! Excellent service to sell.

The base salary is good. Benefits for senior professionals include a vehicle (not fuel though). The medical insurance plan is good as is their retirement plan. The company philosophy of "People-Service-Profit" (in that order) is part of the oganizational culture and fabric. The work/life balance is excellent and allows for remote work from home. Management is fair.  The organization offers very diverse opportunities for a project manager. It's a good place for a long term career.
cons: The management, the management style, the underhand workings, the pay, the breaks or virtual complete lack of.
Worst management I've ever experienced
TNT acquisition is causing challenges but will be resolved in the long term. I wish them all the best of luck.
I'm working 2 years for this com[any never been promoted.
limited opportunity to grow specially in IT Canada

Tedious admin work- almost daily. Endless reports and reports of reports. New action items. Working for an enormous company there is significant projections to have for management weekly. Many of these mundane tasks interfere with the true role of the job- SALES! Account maintenance and service takes up a significant amount of time.
low pay low career opportunities
Crap lorries, always breaking down

No life balance.  Pay cuts 5% that we w I'll never get back. Benefits more expensive every yr.  dental vision difficult to find providers w/in network.  Sales goals so out of reach they are not attainable.  First yr since I've worked here that I will not make a bonus 0for 4 .   Many AEs in same boat. My take home has declined by $10k for two yrs in a row now.  Headed in wrong direction.   FedEx constantly changes and we've always said to just hng on because if something is going on that is bad, things will always change. But now we joke that e're afraid of what's next.   Big mistake combining FXF and parcel sales forces.  They've weakened the quality of the sales force by doing that, crowded territories and overloaded their sales force with too much to learn to be good at anything.

Their bonus opportunity is not that great. Company cars do not include fuel costs. Their philosophy of putting people first has its drawbacks as perception management is a key skill for management (and project managers) to master. The functional organization structure and culture of silos can be complex to overcome for a project manager. Being an American based organization you may be required to work early evenings from time to time depending on the project. Staff turnover is low which does require one to have patience if professional advancement is an objective.

review: Overall its a good company but the company lives with the success of its past.
Good place to work; awful place to have a life.
Receive full benefits and a guaranteed minimum paycheck while still being a part time worker.
I have found my experience to be professionally fulfilling.
Decent compensation, lots of attitude from management
pros: Good salary , workers are good

Fun
great people
Good brand to sell
The benefits, the front line people who actually do the work are great at what they do and there is a tremendous amount of teamwork.

Benefits like health insurance, study tuition up to 3000€; good salary; job stability; constant training; good internal network among other stations and colleagues; work indepently without upper management behind you; no fear from upper management for doing something wrong.

- Deep corporate resources for equipment, supplies, job tools
- Good education benefits
- Good bonuses (if the company is doing well)
- Tries to improve
- Has some agile, intelligent, hard-working employees

After 3 months probationary period you receive full benefits even when one is just a part time worker. As long as you work your normal work week you will be paid your guaranteed minimum even if you work less than that (if you work over your minimum you get paid that amount). Good opportunities to move up through the company. Get discounts with a wide variety of companies that are somehow associated with the company.

FedEx provides professional staff and management with a fast paced and challenging environment that keeps you engaged and constantly learning.  Great benefits, competitive compensation and great people to work with.
Well structured corporation throughout the world with a great people philosophy. With the right management, this is a great company to work for.
Good for student without a responsibility, most of the jobs are part time. Excessive use of temporary hand workers instead of part timers. Non unionized. Benefits if you get a PPT. IF.

- Pay and benefits are quite competitive in the entry level positions.
- Direct management/supervisor is often quite congenial.
- Training received may be useful in other jobs/careers.
cons: Too much work, they force you to work long hr, never take your suggestions into consideration
Comms and bonus and no opportunities

The managment are complacent and have not initated change in operations/service offering or have no clue of what their strategy is to take on the domestic or for that matter the cross border market.  They are too cozy amongst each other and there should be change.  They live in the glory of their past, the term what got us here won't keep us here comes to mind.

extreme working hours; shifts change at anytime due to sick leaves or vacations; if you don't say "yes" to every shift change (or any change, or anything that your manager expects from you) don't expect to be considered for special job opportunities or special training; everyone is involved in their own objective; teamwork is incouraged but not expected; your left on your own to solve big problems because management is no where to be found.

- Moves ponderously slowly (if at all) on intelligent suggestions from the experts the company employs
- Misses ENORMOUS money-making opportunities because of management turf wars
- Moves lightning-fast on pet projects promoted by upper management
- Wastes money investing in poorly managed and under-analyzed initiatives
- Terrible at follow-through on long-term projects
- Terrible at internal communications (can be very "siloed")
- You need to be excellent at tooting your own horn to advance
- Annual employee reviews are more a matter of defending yourself rather than collaborating with management and documenting your successes and learning experiences
- Awards and advancement can be based on favoritism and the "halo" effect
- Management quality is spotty
- Has shockingly few safeguards/redundancies in place to ensure quality/thoroughness of work
Depending on your job it does not require much thinking. While job openings are available at times it can be hard to advance up in the company especially if you are trying to remain in one area.

Memphis is not among my favorite cities, and if you want to advance up the ranks in FedEx you need to do a hitch at WHQ.  There are plenty of nice suburbs, but with a young family there are numerous other cities in which I'd prefer to call home.

Those same great people philosophy's are not always adhered to in the UK by sale management. 
There culture that a sales professionals performance can be directly affected by sales management failures does not exist. Performance improvement plans (PIP) is the first stage of a rocky road for a sales professional in the UK and it is not often used in the way it was intended which is as a support mechanism.

No movement between divisions; you are stuck. 
The different divisions (Express, Office, Ground, Custom critical...) behave as silos, same as each country where it works. Open the doors of the cross training an use the resources without borders.  Difficult to grow and closed groups handle the development. Too much overhead in operations. 
Poor use of technology. FedEx operations is just labor. Non unionized.

- A company that is very good at superficially making it appear it cares about its entry-level workers but in reality treats them like cogs in a machine.  It would be helpful if they were at least honest about this.
- Extremely rude payroll staff in Tennessee you will have to make most of the phone calls to if you have a problem, despite this being presumably HR's job.
- Senior management can be quite strange and hostile, making arbitrary rules for little to no reason that benefit no one other than a select few.

review: Company will do anything for its clients, must also focus on its staff more.
Reputation not always a good measure opportunity.
pros:
Great people in a team-oriented environment. I spent 25 years there, and learned invaluable skills that have served me well since I left. I was generally happy with the managers I worked for, and the culture was people-friendly, fast-paced, and fun.

From a work standpoint, there were always interesting, challenging projects that kept me interested and engaged. We weren't afraid to push the envelope on technology, and most of the time I could see how my efforts contributed to the bottom line.

Over the years, I developed a wonderful network of professional associates and friends, and will always value my time at Fedex.
They paid within the industry standards, though I could never get the answer to the question if we were paid in comparison to other staff that did tracing.

If You are just looking for a place to earn extra money and have rest of the day avaible for school or regular job package handler is good job. Good, hard worker with lots of initiative will find a very favorable environment for lots of personal and professional growth. Employees are rewarded based on performance.I found it is good company where employees are valued and it is posssible to progress within company from package handler to managing positions.Often company subdise education efforts.
We are encouraged to find better ways of doing things.  Do the right things right and you are pretty much left alone to get things done.

People
There is a strong committment to doing the right thing for the customer. 
Very positive vibe for new technology 
Challenging and interesting industry
Good team of colleagues. bad coffee, good internal learning program

Fedex is the best company i have ever worked for they are a forward think company. I have come from LGV driver to driver trainer and been supported all the way by my manager and the whole of the transport team. FedEx is a great place to work we do team work.

FedEx is a satisfactory job to start with as a young person,  but beware.  It will take the average driver (courier) over ten years to "top out" at pay.  FedEx is best to be used as a job to supplement full time college courses while working towards a degree.  When said degree is achieved, run don't walk away from FedEx.
Reputable company with flexible work environment and decent benefits package.  Opportunities to work with all types of companies and customers.

No other jobs out there right now and there's stll a lot of potential, if the company will just begin listening to those of us who know how to grow the business.  The people who are left are still just as dedicated as they ever were and it is a privilege to work with them.
cons:
Fedex is BIG, and the challenges of managing that size of organization has led to an over-reliance on rules and procedures that tend to hider productivity and innovation. More and more, it is losing the ability to respond to market pressures and opportunities in a timely fashion.

Additionally, the company has lost the managerial edge that propelled its success in early years. They have acquired a glut of mid-level corporate survivors who rely more on preserving the status-quo than taking the risks necessary for competitive success. 

From an employee standpoint, a job at Fedex is not as secure as it once was. While they formerly had a no-layoff policy, they have abandoned it. Layoffs aren't frequent, but they are now part of the Fedex culture, with the attendant effects on morale.

minimal training,  limited opportunities for advancement, favoritism, lack of management oversight, dishonesty, inadequate facilities and equipment, at times dangerous, no one available to answer human resources or benefit questions. They seem to have someone on staff who's only job is to look for ways to deny health insurance claims.
Job is very physicaly demanding. Shift starts at 1am and finishes around 6am.If you are looking for a repetitive, predictable task job, you will find what you are looking for here.
The recent pay cuts, salary suspensions, cut in incentive pay, and the cut in 401K match have really hurt and make it hard to keep up with inflation.

Salaries....national pay grade is same for high cost areas of Eastern US and  Mid West urban as in mid south. No visibility  to how salary range is determined geographically.  Hush hush attitude in regard to salary.
Very hard to move up in company if not located in Memphis.  
Difficult to obtain training outside of Memphis, it's all online and not very good

to many managers who look up, and forget to look down to the workers, all the time budget cuts work with FedEx now for more than 12 years. all extra bonus and or Employee Benefits are cut back, or shut down over a period of 10 years now. this crisis will not help to improve these bonus or benefits back soon.
As far as i am  concerned there are no cons this is a GREAT company  with Great people working together to make FedEx the number 1 in the world (which i think we are)

Slavish work atmosphere.  Negativity at all times from management concerning your job performance.  Rampant favoritism by management towards selected employees.  Zero tolerance for mistakes.  Failure of this company to keep pace with the cost of living.  The worst couriers go into management, perpetuating the "us vs. them" (courier vs. management) mentality.  Courier pay stagnates, management pay increases.

Opportunites for advancement in technology positions are difficult live in Memphis and know the right people. Software not as reliable as service. Some software technologies not keeping up with market.
Pay cuts, layoffs, benefits reductions, poor strategic decisions, idiotic tactical decisions, and a leadership in personal survival mode with no concept of long-term planning.

review: At Least I Have a Job and Healthcare

Great job (if you don't mind overtime)
A truly great global company headquartered in the USA.
Co-workers and management were fantastic but indeed back breaking.
FedEx is a great company to work for
Learn alot about the structure and the importance of chain of command in business
pros:
Healthcare
Don't have to interact with customers or anyone I don't feel like talking to
Physical job that keeps me toned
I am employed which is more than many can say

Great pay
Great benefits
Many opportunities for promotion
Nice people

This is a company that really understands the fact that their business is dependent on their labor workers, and they treat them well.  The pay is great, with wage increases happening every 1, 3, 6, 9 and 12 months, and then every year for four years.  The benefits are great, after six months of employment part timers are eligible for PTO and other benefits, as well as the opportunity to switch to full time.  The management staff really seems to have a legitimate care about safety and are very encouraging, motivating, and polite.  Management thanks package handlers after every shift and every two weeks or so they have a "package handler appreciation day" and give out cookies, cupcakes, or even sometimes a catered snack such as bagels or hot dogs.  Also, they will tell you that FedEx is one of the few places where you can start as a package handler and work your way up without a college degree, and it is true that hard workers are quickly spotted and promoted.  This is a great job for someone who is willing to provide tough physical labor, and can be great as a summer job or as a career starter.
My co-workers are the first thing to come to mind. They really make the company. Beniefits are fine and there's opportunity for advancement if one so desires.

Friendly people, good atmosphere and modern office with canteen downstairs.  Lots of customs rules to learn but colleagues are super helpful.  Benefits are nice.  Job is pretty secure as long as you can work fast and accurately on repetitive tasks - they are always looking to increase the team.  Pay is fine for a first job in a corporation. Some opportunity to 'move up' eg. as a team leader.

FedEx offers a very dynamic and fast-paced work environment.  They take great pride in hiring the best and brightest people so that they require little direct management involvement to get the mission at hand accomplished.  There is a great deal of personal leeway granted as long as results match expectations.

Most employees at FedEx were friendly and management was amazing. The hub manager was always on floor, and the assistant manager had weekly meetings to ensure everyone was working together. An overall good experience.
I worked in FedEx Services and the people are great and talented. It is not a high stress environment but each team member Contributes a lot.

Flat organization
Lots of freedom
Easy access to hierarchy

Your opinion is valued
It is a good place work if you are a team player.. there training is top notch. and they have great benefits and perks.
stand for quality, speed, customer focus, efficiency, thinking outside of the box, employee empowerment, leadership excellence, flat organization
cons:
Ever shortening shifts
Dangerous work conditions like bad drivers on tugs and who-knows-what coming down the line (hazardous materials; poorly wrapped packages; broken glass)
Incompetent management
Lazy and intellectually challenged co-workers
No mobility, just fake lateral moves
Healthcare is way too expensive, $100/week for the family plan.

Hard work
Hours (Depending on your shift)
Weather

The cons that I listed are not really FedEx's fault...  Just know that while you are paid well and given great benefits, this is a labor based job and you are expected to work hard for the duration of your shift (usually 3-4 hours off season, but as much as 5 during busy season).  The warehouses are not climate controlled so it is very hot and muggy in the summer and you WILL sweat, so make sure you bring a water bottle.  Management is very understanding and they provide gatorade and allow you to take short breaks to fill your bottle during your shift.  Also, some of the shifts are terrible hours (like 3AM - 8AM or 9PM to 2AM), but these shifts are also paid more and often are easy to get hired into, if you are willing to alter your sleep schedule.  Overall though, all of the cons relate to the nature of the job and not the company itself.

Like all successful companies, they must answer to the stockholders and this sometimes leaves some employee with the feeling  they dont matter to the company. The couriers make up the majority of the company, yet they are the only employees not given any kind of bonus/pay incentives.

Lots of compulsory overtime which to be fair is paid well (100% more), sometimes an hour extra per day, sometimes shorter, occasionally even longer than an hour. Overtime depends on when the tasks are finished by the whole team, so you cannot predict what time you'll go home in advance. 

Lots of pressure to work quickly. Tasks are repetitive but you have to keep alert in case of anything unusual.  This can be a bit stressful.

Holidays are very inflexible and you may not be granted your request, even if you ask months ahead of time - this applies to several months in the year, not only the obvious flashpoints like Christmas or August.  No Polish national holidays are given automatically - you may take the day off at a different time instead or be paid extra.

Be aware that if you are a 'native' English speaker, or near native then you may well be asked to join the small team calling out to customers. Customers are usually friendly (or neutral) so this is not a bad task, but some colleagues were disappointed to be moved to this team as they don't like to speak on the phone.
Stiff competition and highly specialized areas of expertise make it difficult to land desirable management jobs even if you are well qualified.
Not recommended to anyone with ANY back or joint problems as there are very heavy packages, and there are a very few counter productive employees.
It is like a barge. It is a huge company that will keep going forward no matter how slow it is, just because of its size. It is impossible to make changes in the organization.

Difficult to manage people due to lack of boundaries on responsibilities, freedom, discipline expected.
People belonging to one team are typically spread over different countries, it's a challenge to manage different personalities, located in different countries, with different cultural backgrounds and very different levels of skills.
Management tends to overthink and avoid taking decisions.
The hub operations relies on a handful of very knowledgeable and senior resources which become unmissable over time. These resources are being overused and are in danger of burning themselves out due to the sheer amount of work getting shifted towards them.

the company promotes mainly through seniority.. you have to get used to policy changes on the regular and and if you are looking to get into management its alot of politics involved more than anything..

Very lean organization. Great in that you learn a lot and have a broad scope of responsibility but one can burn out if one is not careful.
The organization was starting to put more distance between upper management and the employee voice... becoming too typical of other organizations. Unfortunately, this can erode their People First philosophy.

review: Strong Senior Management, strong and well run company, put employees 1st....career advancement limited
This is a great company to work for. A lot of opportunities and FedEx encourages the employees to grow their career
YBZ location downtown is poorly managed
Very good company, model is getting outdated for the size,  opportunity relies on local management
Overall, great company, top leadership terrific.
pros: Great experience, great brand name.  Strong financially to withstand economic downturn which is big plus.  People first philosphy is evident.
The salary and package are great. Work life balance, peaceful environment, nice people working around here. It is just like a huge and warm family
The one good thing I can say is they pay well. That's probably the only reason anyone would work there.
Slightly above average pay (vs. UPS, Purolator, etc.), pretty flexible with hours. Most employees are down to earth and make time at the station enjoyable.
Almost nothing will get you fired
Because England is my dream country and I love to work there. I want to learn some more.

Great Company that practices P-S-P, People, Service Profit equally.  Global Fortune 500 company with immediate name recognition and a very good reputation.  

Strong leadership that has a clear vision of the future.

A great deal of autonomy and decision making ability.

The Salary, Benifit, environment and performance pay is really attractive. I'd say I could grow old here. I admire how the company value and supports it people. Somehow, you have a lot of room to grow and progress here.
The health and dental benefits are good but can be upgraded to great for a little more money. College tuition reimbursement, if your field of study is within approved list.
Brand name recognition, high caliber past sales history of FedEx Express.
cons: Career opportunities are limited unless you network intensively.  Advancement not always offered to best qualified but to "who you know".

Eroding benefits, blatant favouritism, elastic rules, poor, unsafe working conditions, no response to valid complaints, poor communication between departments, management decision are not based on facts or logic, hours are irregular, no recognition for seniority. Management has a disconnect between what the employees actually do. Inconsistent goals.

Station manager clearly not concerned with people. Staff at YBZ is given fewer and fewer hours or crazy split shifts. Takes YEARS to work up to even being eligible to get a full-tim position so almost everyone is part time. When part timers complain, they are replaced with 1 or 2 "casual" employees. No job stability. SFA (Survey, Feedback, Action) meetings, where managers "want" to hear from their workgroups regarding issues, etc., are a complete farce. Nothing changes. Improvements don't happen.

You got only couriers as execs, no vision, risk nor real word or other company related experience. Very short sighted and "dumb" all knowing execs at local or divisional level. Worldwide leadership team is within the best out there. Mr Smith and Mr Bronzeck are realy on another league

Benefits of working. Working, whether paid or unpaid, is good for our health and wellbeing. It contributes to our happiness, helps us to build confidence and self-esteem, and rewards us financially. Because of these benefits, it is important to return to work as soon as possible after an illness or injur

From a HR standpoint a great deal of hourly employees to support and very policy driven because of the highly regulatory environment of the operation.  

A little behind the times from an internal technology standpoint.
Depending on your job description, but for me I guess work-life balance is definitely a problem send my job needs most of my time to work, and less time to be with my family

My day started around 4 AM and 2:30 AM during peak season. 
When a plane is late and all you have to do is wait, they force you to schedule a break on your time-card.
Dilution of general business acumen in the sales force ranks.

review: FedEx is an excellent company to work with because it recognises that its employees are key to it's success.

Great CEO, Good leadership - too big if you are looking to advance
outstanding 14 years, hardwork is required to secure promotion and growth, expectation from employees are high

pros:
Fortune 100 Company
The company has exceptional visionary leadership
The company values and rewards it's people

very good health benefits - growth is always available if you want it.  you just have to be willing to go after it.
I like meeting people, whilst out and doing my daily deliveries. And work in a team, to get all trucks empty smoothly and safe.

freedom to do the right thing, less interference from upper management, well run company, great leadership and vision from the management. They are generally employee friendly and promote from within.
cultural diversity, opportuntiy for advancement, training resources, team work, excellent benefits, great brand recognition, best in the business, always growing and changing.

cons:
Complex business model that takes a new comer awhile to learn

Cannot learn more from FedEx IT department.

Innovation mentality seems to be lacking
Advancement very tough - no one leaves and it seems that it is hard to crack the management bubble unless you are connected.
Much of the flying is at night. This is part of the business. Each pilot develops techniques to deal with circadian rhythm issues and managing fatigue.
sometimes the hours are limited- and the work is hard (but that's no seceret) - and management can be a pain because some act like drill sgts!

Once trucks are unloaded . Loading your vans up to 100 drops a day. They leaving yard and making
Sure all your customers get there delivery that day
long working hours, less work life balance
large corporate structure sometimes there is disconnect from department to department.  lots of change constantly happening and sometimes lines get crossed.

You don't create a culture out of thin air, for a big part you hire it... Because FedEx doesn't fire people the good people eventually leave and the bad ones end up getting promoted. As a result middle management is often clueless, lazy, under-qualified, over-staffed and grossly overpaid. There are no career paths for young ambitious professionals because they are not allowed to progress (mostly out of fear). The focus is put on internal political games that further hurt the advancement of good people... HR is a hot mess. FedEx Express Europe can be a lot more efficient than it is today but again it is unclear if middle management would accept or applaud these advancements... mostly because they would make their own positions redundant if they would do so...

review: Don't work for FedEx as a courier!

It is a nice workplace environment. I work from home
pros: Working at corporate HQ in Memphis was different than any other corporation I have ever worked.  No one worked >40 hours/week.   It was a very relaxed environment, come in between 7-9, take a long lunch if y ou please and leave between 4-6.  Very friendly place and co-workers.
Not having your boss around all day.  Checking out all the hot receptionists.  Working outside in the summer time.  Seeing all the women walking around all day downtown!

Competitive pay for the industry.  Great product/service offerings backed by a well known and respected brand name.  FedEx hires top notch people and I made life-long friendships and connections with co-workers.
Very friendly environment and wise management, team work and dynamic workplace and very enthusiastic . IT manger was a real leader and always supporting my new ideas and initiatives
great benefits, sound business and company to work for. they treat employees fairly well and have updated computer applications and equipment.

Working at home, and can dress anyway i like.  Great benefits to working at home.  people are always nice.

1. An ocean to Learn with supportive environment
2. Decent pay 
3. Work - Life balance average
cons:
Working at corporate HQ in Memphis was different than any other corporation I have ever worked.  
-Overstaffed, not enough to keep you busy.
-People stay in position for 20+ years because they are comfortable,  not because they excel at their job. 
-Managers promoted based on diversity, not necessarily merit.

Last few years treated the couriers like garbage, even though we are the face of company!  There was a lot of favoritism going on the past few years!  Can't advance through the company at all!  Ripped off with benefits.  Lost all bonuses but having to do more work then we did in the past!  Get no bonus for driving around in the snow, told to work faster but try to be safe!

FedEx has been off-track for a while and has turned away from the "People First" mentality that it still touts.  Age discrimination is alive and well!  It's hard to swallow that FedEx is in the midst of a  major downsizing e.g., sales office closures, the big BuyOut of 2013 and yet Fred Smith takes a record pay raise and bonus plan as a reward.
Always loaded with tasks and many times worked for more than 20 continuous hours. That should have rationalized by increasing resource and additional training
downsizing and making the reduced workforce responsible for more than they can sometimes handle. very fast paced and distracting at times. upper management disengaged from workers and issues.
Currently I have not seen any cons so far in my present time working for my employer.
In recent years the culture fundamentally changed in a negative way owing to a new direction taken by the leadership team.
Professional advancement is limited in most cities outside of Memphis which is corporate headquarters.  Pay raises aren't the best but bonuses are pretty good.
As Speciality rep you are expected to know everything.  Jack of all trades and a master of none.

My biggest surprise and perhaps disappointment is that the technology the company uses is so antiquated. For most people, looking up addresses on a map can be tedious and time consuming. When you are new, that is the way it is done.

Try to imagine doing this manual look up for 70-100 packages/envelopes a day and then trying to frame that into a route/run where you are minimizing (or trying to minimize) the amount of time you spend doubling back on yourself. Of course, if you have a regular route, over the weeks and months you will improve in this regard but for someone new it is almost tragic. 

I am sure that eventually they will incorporate more GPS and the morning sorts and truck set-ups will carry a higher degree of automation but for now things are firmly embedded in the early 1990's.
